furnished with a rudder, Arist. Cat. 7a12.

definition: πηδάω, E. Ion 717 (lyr.), etc.; Dor. 3 sg. παδῇ Sophr. 20; Lacon. imper. πάδη Ar. Lys. 1317 (lyr.); Ion. part. πηδεῦντα, πηδεῦσαι, Herod. 3.96, 4.61 : fut. - ήσομαι Thphr. Char. 21.6, ( ἐπι-) Pl. Ly. 216a, ( προσ-) Alex. 124.16; later - ήσω APl. 16.54*, 142 : aor. ἐπήδησα Il. 14.455, etc.: pf. πεπήδηκα Aesop. 203, ( ἀπο-) Hp. Art. 47, ( ἐκ-) X. HG 7.4.37, ( ὑπερ-) D. 23.73 :— Pass., plpf. ἐπεπήδητο (in act. sense) Hp. Nat.Puer. 13:—

children.definition: leap, spring, ὑψόσε ποσσὶν ἐπήδα Il. 21.269, cf. 302 ; ἐς σκάφη π. S. Aj. 1279 ; πρὸς πυγήν Hp. Nat.Puer. l.c.; opp. βαδίζω, X. Cyn. 5.31 ; of fish in the frying-pan, Eub. 75.6, 109, al.: c. acc. cogn., π. δυστυχῆ πηδήματα E. Or. 263; π. μείζονα (sc. πηδήματα) S. OT 1300 (anap.); λαιψηρὰ π. E. Ion 717 (lyr.): c. acc. loci, πεδία π. bound over them, S. Aj. 30; π. πλάκα E. Ba. 307.
stamp with the feet, οἱ φίλοι πηδάτωσαν Luc. Rh. Pr. 21.

children.label: II
children.definition: οὐκ ὀΐω . . ἅλιον πηδῆσαι ἄκοντα Il. 14.455 ; πάλος . . ʼπήδησεν εὐχάλκου κράνους A. Th. 459; τροχοὶ π. E. Ph. 1194 : freq. of the heart or pulse, leap, throb, ἁ καρδία παδῇ Sophr. l.c., cf. Pl. Smp. 215e : folld. by interrog. clause, οἶμαι τὰς καρδίας πηδᾶν ὅ τι λέξει Ar. Nu. 1392 ; κατὰ δʼ ἐγκέφαλον πηδᾷ σφάκελος E. Hipp. 1352 ; πηδῶσα οἷον τὰ σφύζοντα Pl. Phdr. 251d; αἱ σάρκες οἷα θερμὰ θερμὰ πηδεῦσαι Herod. 4.61 ; of the mind, πηδῶν ὁ θυμὸς ἔνδοθεν μαντεύεται Trag.Adesp. 176, cf. 390 ; of sudden change, τί πηδᾷς ἄλλοτʼ εἰς ἄλλους τρόπους E. Tr. 67; εἰς τἀπίσημα δʼ ὁ φθόνος πηδᾶν φιλεῖ Id. Fr. 294 ; π. πρός τινος εὐπραγίαν Philostr. VS 2.25.4.

data.quote: οἶμαι τὰς καρδίας πηδᾶν ὅ τι λέξει
αἱ σάρκες οἷα θερμὰ θερμὰ πηδεῦσαι
τί πηδᾷς ἄλλοτʼ εἰς ἄλλους τρόπους
εἰς τἀπίσημα δʼ ὁ φθόνος πηδᾶν φιλεῖ

children.definition: pulsation, φλεβῶν Hp. Epid. 7.39.
leap, bound, A. Pers. 95, 305, S. Aj. 833, E. Andr. 1139, etc., cf. πηδάω I; leaping up in admiration, of an audience, Plu. Aud. 2.41c (pl.).

children.label: II
children.definition: beating or throbbing of the heart, τὸ μέλλον καρδία πήδημʼ ἔχει E. Ba. 1288; ἴσχεσθαι καρδίαν πηδήματος Plu. Profect. 2.83b.
leaping, πηδήσεις σατυρικαί Plu. Ant. 75; πηδήσεις ἐπὶ τοὺς ἵππους Arr. Tact. 43.3; of wood burning, Thphr. Ign. 69.

children.label: II
children.definition: beating or throbbing of the heart, Pl. Ti. 70c, Lg. 791a, Arist. PA 669a20, Phld. Ir p.27 W.
leaper, dancer, Ptol. Tetr. 64.
good at leaping, springing, of the locust, grasshopper, flea, Arist. HA 532a27, PA 683a33 : Sup. - ώτατος, σατύρων Luc. Bis Acc. 10.
made of πηδός, read by Gramm. for φήγινος in Il. 5.838, Hsch., EM 669.40, Eust. 613.9.
blade of an oar: hence generally, oar, ἀναρρίπτειν ἅλα πηδῷ Od. 7.328, cf. 13.78 ; πηδοῖσιν ἐρέσσετε A.R. 4.200 ; γῆ δὲ ναυσθλωθήσεται ῥήσσοντι πηδοῖς χέρσον Lyc. 1416.

data.quote: γῆ δὲ ναυσθλωθήσεται ῥήσσοντι πηδοῖς χέρσον

children.label: II
children.definition: πηδά, = πηδάλια, Arat. 155. (Written πῆδον, also πῆδος, Hsch.)
Thphr. HP 5.7.6; perh. = πάδος (q. v.); cf. πήδινος. (Variously accented in codd.)

definition: πηδύειν, πηδυλίς, written for πιδ-, Hsch.

children.definition: πηρός, Phlp. in Cat. 180.24, EM 671.1. (Inferred from παθεῖν.)
Dim. of παῖς, child, son, Supp.Epigr. 2.509.5 ( Crete, v B. C.).

definition: πήκασμα, ατος, τό, f.l., perh. for πύκασμα, in pl.,

children.definition: trappings for horses, Hippiatr. 14.

definition: πηκτή, Dor. πακτά, ἡ, v. πηκτός.
πήκτης, dub. sens. in Arch.Pap. 5.387 (ii A. D.).

children.definition: freezing, Thphr. CP 6.1.3 : Comp., ib. 5.14.3.
coagulating, curdling, γάλακτος Dsc. 1.128.

definition: πηκτίς, Dor. πᾱκτίς, ίδος, Aeol. πᾶκτις, ιδος, ἡ,

children.definition: stringed instrument used by the Lydians, Sapph. 122, Alc. Supp. 5.5, Pi. Fr. 125, Hdt. 1.17, S. Frr. 241 (pl.), 412, Telest. 5.4 (pl.), Sopat. 11; played with finger (not πλῆκτρον), Aristox. Fr.Hist. 66 : pl., Ar. Th. 1217, Pl. R. 399c, Arist. Pol. 1341a40, Anaxil. 15; said to have been introduced (from Lydia) by Sappho, Menaechm. 5; later, = λύρα, Luc. DMar. 1.4.
shepherdʼs pipe, Panʼs pipes, APl. 16.244 ( Agath.); ἐπὶ χείλεσι σύρων π. AP 9.586 ( Cometas), cf. Procop.Gaz. p.137 B.
cage or net for catching birds, in pl., Dionys. Av. 3.1, Sch. Ar. Av. 528.

children.label: II
children.definition: carving-knife, Suid.

definition: πηκτός, ή, όν, Dor. πᾱκτός, ά, όν, (πήγνυμι I)

children.definition: stuck in, fixed, ἔγχος ἐν χθονί S. Aj. 907; π. θάνατος, of the death of Ajax, Trag.Adesp. 255.
planted, opp. raised from seed, [ σκόροδον] Thphr. HP 7.4.11 : πηκτή, ἡ, a variety of σύμφυτον (q.v.), Dsc. 4.10.

children.label: II
children.definition: well put together, compacted, built, of wood-work, ἄροτρον Il. 10.353, Od. 13.32; opp. αὐτόγυος, Hes. Op. 433; π. ἕδος a chair of several pieces, h.Cer. 196; π. κλίμακες E. Ph. 489 ; π. λύραι S. Fr. 238 (anap.).
πηκτή, ἡ, net or cage set to catch birds, Ar. Av. 528, Arist. HA 614a12; cf. πηκτίς I.3.
πηκτὰ δωμάτων barriers of the house, door, E. Fr. 1003 ( πακτὰ codd. Poll.), parodied in Ar. Ach. 479.

children.label: III
children.definition: congealed, curdled, γάλα E. Cyc. 190; πακτά, ἡ, cream-cheese, Theoc. 11.20, cf. AP 6.55 ( Barb.), POxy. 1923.19 (pl., v/vi A. D.); ἃλς π. salt obtained from brine. Nic. Al. 518; κηρός Theoc. 1.128; frozen, ὕδατα Pl. Ti. 59c ; ὕδωρ τὸ μὲν ῥέον τὸ δὲ πακτόν Ti.Locr. 99c.

data.quote: ὕδωρ τὸ μὲν ῥέον τὸ δὲ πακτόν

children.definition: capable of solidification, Arist. Mete. 385a12.
πῆλαι, v. πάλλω.
made of clay, πλίνθος Man. 4.292.

children.label: II
children.definition: living in mud, of fish, Paus. 4.34.2.

definition: πηλακίζω, etym. of προπηλακίζω, EM 669.49, cf. πήλαξ; also found in PSI 5.495.9 (iii B. C.).
πηλακισμός, ὁ, etym. of προπηλακισμός, Suid.

children.definition: tunny-fishery, Str. 12.3.19.
fishing-ground for tunnies, Str. 12.3.11.
young tunny (of the first year, acc. to Arist. HA 571a11), S. Fr. 503, Phryn.Com. 35, Hices. ap. Ath. 3.116e, Sostrat. ap. eund. 7.303b, Opp. H. 1.113, 4.504; vas pelamydum, Juv. 7.120.
πηλακίζω, EM 669.49.
eye-salve, Aët. 7.9 (pl.), Alex.Trall. 2.

definition: Πηλεύς, ὁ, gen. έως, Ep. ῆος or εος, acc. έα (monosyll.) S. Fr. 487, E. Andr. 22 :—

children.definition: Peleus, Il. 18.18, etc.; Πηλέως μάχαιρα, prov. of unexpected aid, Sch. Ar. Nu. 1059 :— Adj. Πήλειος, α, ον AP 9.476b; Ep. Πηλήϊος, η, ον Il. 18.60; Patron. Πηλεΐδης, ου, Ep. εω and αο, ὁ, son of Peleus, 15.64, 614; Ep. also Πηληϊάδης, 1.1; Dor. Πηλεΐδας Pi. P. 6.23 :—also Πηλεΐων, ωνος, ὁ, Il. 16.195, etc. (also as name of a frog, with play on πηλός, Batr. 206); Πηλεΐωνάδε to Peleus’ son, Il. 24.338. (Popularly derived from πηλός (which however has ᾱ in Dor.): hence prov. μὴ δεῖν τὸν Οἰνέα Πηλέα ποιεῖν donʼt make wine into lees, Ath. 9.383c, cf. Demetr. Eloc. 171.)
helmet, ἀμφὶ δέ οἱ κροτάφοισι φαεινὴ σείετο πήληξ Il. 13.805 ; ἤμυσε κάρη πήληκι βαρυνθέν 8.308; ἱππόκομος π. 16.797; old Ep. word, used by Ar. Ra. 1017, Arist. Top. 173b20.

data.quote: ἀμφὶ δέ οἱ κροτάφοισι φαεινὴ σείετο πήληξ

children.definition: crest, E. Hyps.Fr. 16(18).4. (Commonly derived from πάλλω, πῆλαι, from the nodding of the plume, Apollon. Lex., etc.)
of or from Mount Pelion, μελίη Il. 16.143, etc.
Hsch.

definition: πηλίκος [ ῐ], η, ον, interrog. correl. to τηλίκος, ἡλίκος,

children.definition: how great or large? πηλίκη τις ἔσται ἡ γραμμή; Pl. Men. 82d, cf. 83e; πηλίκον τινὰ οἴεσθε μέγεθος; Eub. 82 ; after τηλικοῦτος, D. 19.284; πόσα καὶ πηλίκα of what number and magnitude, Plb. 1.2.8 : with Art., ὁ πηλίκος; quantulus? Babr. 69.4; τὸ π. magnitude, opp. τὸ ποσόν (quantity), Nicom. Ar. 1.2 ; ὁ χρόνος . . ἐστὶ μῖγμα πηλίκου καὶ ποσοῦ Dam. Pr. 371. Adv. - κως Hdn.Gr. 2.925.

data.quote: ὁ χρόνος . . ἐστὶ μῖγμα πηλίκου καὶ ποσοῦ

children.label: II
children.definition: of what age, π. ἦσθʼ ὅθʼ ὁ Μῆδος ἀφίκετο; Xenoph. 22.5.
of a certain age, Arist. EN 1134b11 : Comp. - ώτερος, f.l. for ἀπηλικέστερος, Aret. SA 2.11.
magnitude, size, A.D. Pron. 26.13, Gal. 1.333, Sch. Ar. Pl. 377 : opp. ποσότης (quantity), Nicom. Ar. 1.7.

definition: πήλινος, η, ον, also ος, ον D.Chr. 31.152 : ( πηλός) :—

children.definition: of clay, ἀνδριὰς π. Arist. Metaph. 1035a32; οἱ π. clay figures, D. 4.26 ; τοῖχοι π. Plu. Dem. 11; π. εἰκόνες D.Chr. l.c.; π. βωμός Com.Adesp. 341; π. ὀξύ pointed nest of clay, built by the mason-bee, Arist. HA 555a14; π. ἔργα PPetr. 3p.143 (iii B. C.).
Pelion, a mountain in Thessaly, Il. 2.757, etc.:— Adj. Πηλιάς (q. v.); Πηλιῶτις, ιδος on or at the foot of Pelion, E. Med. 484; Πηλιωτικός, ή, όν, S. Fr. 154; Πηλιακός, ή, όν, APl. 16.110.
mud-walker, name of a frog, v.l. in Batr. 241.
born from clay, = γηγενής, used of the giants in Call. Jov. 3 (but Πηλαγόνες, Pelagonians, Hdn.Gr. 1.24).
make mortar, IG 2(2).1672.29.
build of clay, θάλαμον AP 10.4 ( Marc. Arg.), cf. 5 ( Thyill.).
clay-built, τοῖχοι AP 9.662 ( Agath.).
coctiliarius, figulus, Gloss.
πήλοι, v. τηλοῦ.
trample in the mire, PMasp. 87.9 ( vi A. D., Pass.).
walk on clay or mud, Sch. Ar. Pax 1148.
mud-treaders, ἀρβύλαι π. a kind of boots with thick soles, Hp. Art. 62 (v.l. πηλοβατίδες ap. Gal. 18(1).680).
potter, Luc. Prom. Es 1.
moulded of clay, π. σπέρμα, of a man, A. Fr. 369.
Mud-Plato, nickname of the sophist Alexander, Philostr. VS 2.5.1.
make muddy, χθόνα Lyc. 473, cf. EM 629.34.

definition: πηλοποιητικός and πηλο-ποιικός, ff. ll. for πιλοπ-.

children.definition: potterʼs trade, PPetr. 2p.32 (iii B. C.), CPHerm. p.80.
BGU 362 viii 8 (iii A. D.), Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.49.

definition: πηλός ( Dor. πᾱλός Sophr. 32, Cerc. 3.3, IG 5(1).1447.16 ( Messene, iii/ii B. C.)), ὁ, Syrac. ἡ Phryn. 38 :—

children.definition: clay, earth, used by masons and potters, Hdt. 2.36, 136, Ar. Av. 1143, Th. 2.76, Pl. Tht. 147a, Plb. 15.35.2; πηλὸν ὀργάζειν Eup. 248, S. Fr. 482, cf. 510, 787, Ar. Av. 839; π. ἠχυρωμένος clay mixed with chaff for use as mortar, IG 2(2).463.42, cf. 5(1) l.c., LXX Ge. 11.3; εὐώδεϊ πηλῷ, of earth on which wine has been poured, Tryph. 349; Βρομιώδεα π. φύρησαν . . Χάριτες, of a drinkingcup, AP 11.27 ( Maced.): metaph., clay from which man was made: hence ὁ π. ὁ Προμηθεῖος, of man, Call. Fr. 87, cf. 133, Ar. Av. 686; ἐκ ποίου πηλοῦ πεφύρητʼ εἰδότα Herod. 2.29.

mud, mire, Hdt. 2.5, 4.28, Ar. V. 248, Th. 2.4, Pl. R. 363d, etc.: prov., ἔξω κομίζειν πηλοῦ πόδα A. Ch. 697; κάσις πηλοῦ ξύνουρος, i. e. dust, Id. Ag. 495: metaph., ἀνέρες ὧν τὸ κέαρ παλῶ σέσακται Cerc. l.c.

data.quote: ἀνέρες ὧν τὸ κέαρ παλῶ σέσακται

children.label: II
children.definition: thick or muddy wine, lees, S. Fr. 783; of wine spilt on the floor, Plu. Cohib. 2.463a, Charito 1.3; cf. Πηλεύς fin.

children.label: III
children.definition: dolt, blockhead, Com. Adesp. 890.
machine for kneading mortar, Stud.Pal. 20.67.20 (ii/iii A. D.).
reared in mud or soft soil, Opp. C. 1.288.

definition: πηλουργία, in Ion. form πηλοεργίη, ἡ,

children.definition: working in clay, Aret. SD 1.6.
working in clay, of bees, Lyr.Alex.Adesp. 7.16: Subst. π., ὁ, LXX Wi. 15.7, Luc. Prom.Es 2, PKlein.Form. 63 (vi A. D.).
Pelusium in Egypt, Hdt. 2.15, etc.:

Πηλουσιώτης, ου, ὁ, inhabitant of P., Luc. JTr. 42; Adj., τὸ Πηλούσιον στόμα the Eastern mouth of the Nile, Hdt. 2.17, 154; τὸ Πηλουσιακὸν στ. Str. 17.1.18; also Ταριχήϊα Πηλουσιακά Hdt. 2.15: Subst. Πηλούσιον, τό, an Egyptian festival, expld. with ref. to πηλός, Lyd. Mens. 4.57.
carry clay or mortar, Ar. Av. 1142, Ec. 310 (lyr.), BGU 699.5 (ii A. D.).
carrying clay or mortar, BGU 1290.3 (ii B.C.), Poll. 7.130, Suid.
moulded of clay, θάλαμοι, of swallows’ nests, AP 10.16 ( Theaet.).

coat or daub with clay, PMag.Berol. 2.151, Gal. 14.291 :— Med., smear oneself with clay, ἁφῇ (cf. ἁφή II 5) πηλώσασθαι IG 42(1).126.11 ( Epid., ii A. D.), cf. Plu. Sollert. 2.980e:— Pass., to be covered with mud, J. AJ 1.3.5, Plu. Vit. aer. al. 2.831a; ὅλον τὸ σῶμα πεπηλωμένος Lyd. Mens. 4.57; to be smeared with clay, Apollod. Poliorc. 147.4; of athletes, Luc. Anach. 6.
rent, cleft, Hsch., Phot.
clayey, muddy, ἀταρπιτός Parm. 20; of places, Th. 6.101, Arist. HA 549b15, etc.; of the river Acheron, Pl. Phd. 113b.

definition: πηλώεις, εσσα, εν, poet. for foreg., Opp. H. 4.520, Nonn. D. 2.59.

children.definition: mud, Charis. p.33 K.
smearing with mud, Plu. Superst. 2.166a (pl.).

definition: πῆμα, ατος, τό (same form in Dor.), poet. word,

children.definition: misery, calamity, π. κακόν Od. 5.179; π. κακοῖο 3.152; δύης π. 14.338; π. τῆς ἄτης S. Aj. 363; π. θεὸς Δαναοῖσι κυλίνδει Il. 17.688; τοῖσι . . πῆμα κυλίνδεται Od. 2.163, cf. Il. 11.347; ἡμῖν πήματα πολλὰ θέσαν 15.721; τοι πῆμα τόδʼ ἤγαγον Οὐρανίωνες 24.547; ἓν παρʼ ἐσλὸν π. σύνδυο δαίονται βροτοῖς ἀθάνατοι Pi. P. 3.81; πημάτων ἔξω πόδα ἔχει A. Pr. 265; πήματα ἐπὶ πήμασι πίπτοντʼ S. Ant. 594 (lyr.); πῆμʼ ἐπὶ πήματι κεῖται, i.e. iron upon iron, the sword forged upon the anvil, Orac. ap. Hdt. 1.67, cf. 68; σοφιστὴς πημάτων deviser of pains (i. e. the labours of Heracles), E. Heracl. 993.

data.quote: ἓν παρʼ ἐσλὸν π. σύνδυο δαίονται βροτοῖς ἀθάνατοι

children.label: II
children.definition: bane, calamity, ὅς μιν ἔτικτε . . π. γενέσθαι Τρωσί Il. 22.421, cf. 3.50, 160, 6.282, S. OT 379; π. κακὸς γείτων Hes. Op. 346. (Cf. Skt. pīyati, Goth. fijan ‘hate’.)

data.quote: ὅς μιν ἔτικτε . . π. γενέσθαι Τρωσί

definition: πημαίνω, Il. 15.42: fut. -ᾰνῶ S. Aj. 1314, OC 837; Ion. - ανέω Il. 24.781: aor. ἐπήμηνα 3.299, S. Tr. 715, Pl. R. 364c; Dor. part. πημάνας [ᾱ] IG 1(2).1085.8 :— Med., fut. πημᾰνοῦμαι Ar. Ach. 842 (s. v.l.), also πημανούμενος in pass. sense, S. Aj. 1155 : Ep. aor. πημήναντο Q.S. 13.379 :— Pass., aor. ἐπημάνθην (v. infr.) :—

children.definition: plunge into ruin, undo, and in milder sense, grieve, distress, π. Τρῶάς τε καὶ Ἕκτορα Il. 15.42; [ Ὅρκος] ἀνθρώπους π. Hes. Th. 232, cf. Thgn. 689; π. τὴν γῆν damage it, Hdt. 9.13; ἄτρακτος θεὸν π. S. Tr. 715; π. τινὰ φαρμάκοις Pl. Lg. 932e; ὑγρότης π. τὰ ὄμματα Arist. Pr. 957b24 : abs., do harm, Il. 24.781, Democr. 258; ὑπὲρ ὅρκια πημήνειαν might work harm in transgression of oaths, Il. 3.299:— Med., ὅρκια πημήναντο violated their oaths, Q.S. l.c.:— Pass., suffer hurt or harm, οὐδέ τις οὖν μοι νηῶν πημάνθη Od. 14.255, cf. 8.563, A. Pr. 336, etc.; ἴσθι πημανούμενος S. Aj. 1155.—Poet. word, used also IG 1(2).18.7 and by Hdt. l.c., Pl. R. l.c., Lg. 862a, 932e, 933e ( Pass.), and in later Prose, as Corn. ND 32 ( Pass.), Porph. Abst. 2.12, Agath. 5.23.

data.quote: οὐδέ τις οὖν μοι νηῶν πημάνθη

children.definition: deserving to be injured, Thgn. 689.
A. Pr. 239 (pl.), 278, 308 (pl.), S. Tr. 1189 (pl.), E. Fr. 682; also ὅπλα μὴ ἐπιφέρειν ἐπὶ πημονῇ with hostile intent, Foed. ap. Th. 5.18.
when? Hdn.Gr. 2.925, Hsch.; cf. ἦμος, τῆμος.
A. Pr. 1058 (pl., anap.), E. Fr. 910.3 (anap.), Orph. Fr. 285.10.
baneful, Orph. Εὐχή 31.

definition: πῆν πῆ καὶ πῆν ἐπὶ τοῦ κατάπασσε καὶ καταπάσσειν, Hsch. (Prob. Dor. contr. forms of *πάω

children.definition: ἐπιπάσσω.)
Hsch.
Hsch. s.v. πηνώμενον ( -όμενον cod.), Phot.
Penelope, Od. 24.194, etc.; Πηνελόπη, first in Hdt. 2.145, Ar. Th. 547; Dor. Πᾱνελόπᾱ AP 6.289 ( Leon.).

definition: πηνέλοψ, Aeol. and Dor. πᾱν-, οπος, ὁ,

children.definition: duck, Alc. 84, Ibyc. 8, Ar. Av. 298, 1302, Ion Trag. 68, Arist. HA 593b23.
thread on the bobbin in the shuttle, woof, and in pl., web, E. Hec. 471 (lyr.), Ion 197 (lyr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: bobbin, spool, AP 6.160 ( Antip. Sid.).
false hair, wig, Luc. DMeretr. 5.3, 11.4, 12.5: distd. from ἔντριχον and προκόμιον, Phot., cf. Poll. 2.30, 10.170.
cheat, gull, Cratin. 319, Hsch. (- ικ- cod., ante πήνην), Suid.; cf. διαπηνηκίζω.
fraud, Hsch. (pl.).
wind thread off a reel for the woof, Philyll. 33, prob. in BGU 1141.34 (i B. C.): generally, wind off a reel, ἐκ ταλάρω π. ἔργα Theoc. 18.32:—later in Act., Orib. Fr. 137.

definition: πηνίκα, interrog. Adv. correl. to τηνίκα and ἡνίκα,

children.definition: at what precise point of time? at what hour? Luc. Sol. 5; π. μάλιστα; about what oʼclock is it? Pl. Cri. 43a, cf. Aeschin. 1.9, Plu. Cat.Mi. 13; πηνίκʼ ἄττα; at about what hour? Ar. Av. 1514; in full, πηνίκʼ ἐστὶν ἄρα τῆς ἡμέρας; ib. 1498; π. τῆς νυκτός; Anon. ap. Suid.
ἐρωτᾷ π. δεῖπνόν ἐστι Men. 367.

children.label: II
children.definition: πότε; when? D. 18.313, Philostr. VA 4.25, Luc. Tim. 4, etc.
φυλάττει πηνίκʼ ἔσεσθε μεστοί D. 18.308.

definition: πηνίον, Dor. πᾱνίον, τό, Dim. (in form) of πῆνος or πήνη,

children.definition: bobbin, spool ( ἄτρακτος, εἰς ὃν εἰλεῖται ἡ κρόκη Hsch.), π. ἐξέλκουσα παρὲκ μίτον Il. 23.762 : pl., τὰ τροχαῖα πανία AP 6.288 ( Leon.), cf. Thphr. HP 6.4.5, AP 6.285 ( Nicarch. (?)); prob. in POxy. 1740.6 (iii/iv A. D.).

data.quote: ἄτρακτος, εἰς ὃν εἰλεῖται ἡ κρόκη

children.label: II
children.definition: pupa, perh. of currant-moth, Abraxas grossulariata, Ar. Fr. 377, Arist. HA 551b6.

children.label: III
children.definition: ornament put on cakes, Poll. 6.79, Hsch.
woof on the spool, AP 6.283; ἱστότονα π. (A.ap.) Ar. Ra. 1315, cf. Sammelb. 5873.6 ( Cyrene).
the weaver, i. e. Athena, Ael. NA 6.57; Dor. dat. Πᾱνίτιδι cj. Mein. for - άτιδι in AP 6.289 ( Leon.).
thread-like, Paus.Gr. Fr. 228.
web, Hsch.
she that freezes the sea, Com.Adesp. 1118.

definition: πῆξις, εως, Ion. ιος, ἡ, ( πήγνυμι)

children.definition: fixing, putting together, esp. of woodwork, θυρωμάτων Pl. Plt. 280d (pl.).
fixing, τοῦ ἀναφορικοῦ Vett.Val. 24.18, cf. Cat.Cod.Astr. 2.196.

children.label: II
children.definition: solidity, πῆξιν λαβεῖν D.S. 1.7 (but metaph., acquire fixity, Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.138, cf. Dam. Pr. 56).

coagulation, Pl. Phlb. 32a; freezing, Hp. Aër. 8; [ ὕδατος] π. Epicur. Ep. 2p.49U., cf. p.45 U.; caused by cold, as τῆξις, διάχυσις, ζέσις by heat, Arist. Mete. 382b31, GC 330b27 (but also π. θερμότητος Ocell. 2.9); formation of gum in plants, Thphr. HP 9.1.5; curdling, γάλακτος D.S. 4.81.

definition: πηός, ὁ, Dor. πᾱός (also in Nic. Th. 3),

children.definition: kinsman by marriage, Il. 3.163, Od. 8.581, 10.441, 23.120, Hes. Op. 345, Call. Fr. 6.8 P.: generally, kinsman, Sammelb. 7423.14 ( Egypt), prob. in Supp.Epigr. 2.461.1 ( Histria). (Wrongly derived from πέπαμαι by Eust. 134.43.)
relationship by marriage, A.R. 1.48.
IG 5(1).213.5 ( Sparta, v B. C.), Theoc. 8.34, Com.Adesp. in Gött.Nachr. 1922 p.28, Epigr. ap. Poll. 4.102.

definition: πήρα, Ion. πήρη ( πάρη [ᾰ] Heraclid. ap. Eust. 29.3), ἡ,

children.definition: leathern pouch for victuals, etc., wallet, Od. 13.437, al., Ar. Pl. 298, Fr. 273, Ostr.Bodl. iii 264 (i A. D.), etc.

definition: πήραξον ἀφόδευσον, Hsch. πηρία<ν>· Ἀ<ς>πένδιοι τὴν χώραν τοῦ ἀγροῦ, Id.

children.definition: Dim. of πήρα, Ar. Nu. 923 (anap.), Fr. 486; π. γνωρισμάτων Men. Epit. 114, cf. Ant.Diog. 6, Hld. 10.9, Porph. Abst. 2.15.

definition: πηρίν or πηρίς (both forms in Choerob. in An.Ox. 2.248), ῖνος, ἡ,

children.definition: scrotum, Nic. Th. 586, Antig. ap. Erot. (not found in text of Hp.); ἐλάφου πηρίς Hsch.
Gal. 19.130 (not in text of Hp.); also cited from Hp. Haem. and Fist., = ἕδρα, ibid.
Hsch.
IG 14.631 ( Locri).
binding a wallet, ἱμάς AP 9.150 (Antip.).
disabled in the limbs, maimed, Epigr. ap. D.L. 5.40.

definition: πηρός ( Dor. πᾱρός implied in ἔμπαρος, παρόω, qq.v.), ά, όν,

children.definition: disabled in a limb, maimed, αἱ δὲ χολωσάμεναι πηρὸν θέσαν [the Muses] made him helpless or blind (cf. Aesop. 57), Il. 2.599; πηρὸς ὁ μὲν γυίοις, ὁ δʼ ἄρʼ ὄμμασι AP 9.11 ( Phil. or Isid.); πηραὶ τὰ σκέλεα Hp. Mul. 2.131.

data.quote: πηρὸς ὁ μὲν γυίοις, ὁ δʼ ἄρʼ ὄμμασι

children.definition: Semon. 7.22; ἀμβλεῖς καὶ π. Ph. 1.624; π. τῷ νῷ Sch. Ar. Pl. 48; πηροὶ οἱ λογισμοί Luc. Am. 46.
loss of strength, dotage, Alc. 98.

maim, mutilate, esp. in the limbs, Ar. Ra. 623; ἐὰν παῖδας ὄντας πηρώσῃ τις castrate, Arist. HA 631 b31; αἴ κα σῦς καρταῖπος παρώσει GDI 4998i14 ( Gortyn): more freq. in Pass., πηροῦται τὸ σκέλος τούτοισι Hp. Art. 60, cf. GDI l.c. i8; τὸ σκέλος πεπηρωμένος D. 18.67; πεπήρωται τοὺς ὀφθαλμούς Arist. HA 620a1, cf. Ephor. 1 J.; so of moles, lobsters, to be defective in point of eyes, claws, Arist. HA 491b34, PA 684a35; ὥσπερ πεπηρωμένον τετράπουν, of the seal, Id. HA 498a32; τὸ πηρωθὲν ἐν τῇ ὑστέρᾳ Id. GA 749a2, etc.

incapacitate, τέχνην . . πηρῶσαι Pl. Phdr. 257a; π. τὴν ἱστορίαν Str. 17.3.3 :— Pass., πεπηρωμένος πρὸς ἀρετήν incapacitated for practising virtue, Arist. EN 1099b19; πρὸς τὴν γνῶσιν Anaxarch. ap. S.E. M. 7.55, cf. 298; πρὸς καρπογονίαν Thphr. CP 1.5.5.
maimed, Hsch. s.v. γυιός.
mutilated or imperfect animal, opp. τέλειον, Arist. de An. 415a27, 432b22, Metaph. 1034b4.

children.label: II
children.definition: Id. GA 746b32, Gal. UP 14.6.
named after a wallet, gloss on οὐλαδώνυμος, Tz.ad Lyc. 183.

maiming, disabling in the limbs or senses, γῆρας ὁλόκληρός ἐστι π. Democr. 296, cf. Arist. EN 1131a9 : freq. in pl., Hp. Art. 61, Pl. Lg. 874e, 925e, Arist. EN 1148b17 ; νόσοι καὶ πηρώσεις ib. 1145a31 ; πήρωσις τῶν ὀφθαλμῶν Plu. QConv. 2.633c, Luc. DMar. 2.4 (abs., blindness, Dsc. 2.180, Plu. An seni 2.791d, Luc. Dom. 29) ; ἀκοῆς Plu. Superst. 2.167c : generally, π. τινὸς αἰσθήσιος Aret. SD 1.4; π. ψυχῆς Man. 4.518 ; of plants, Thphr. HP 2.4.3, 4.14.8 (pl.).
Corinn. Supp. 2.51, 76 (but Boeot. Inscrr. have nom. παις (prob. = πάϊς), v. παῖς).

definition: πῆσις, late form for πεῖσις (from πάσχω), Olymp. in Cat. 99.22.

children.definition: πήγνυμι, LXX Si. 14.24, Ph. 1.420, Dsc. 4.188, Arr. Epict. 1.19.4, S.E. M. 9.247, ( κατα-) Str. 4.3.5, D.H. 3.22 : impf. ἔπησσον Satyr. 1 :— Pass. πήττομαι Antig. Mir. 174, Str. 13.4.14, 7.3.18 ( συμ-).
measure by the cubit, Sm., Al. Ez. 43.13, Supp.Epigr. 6.636 (Termessus Major).

definition: πηχίσκος, ὁ, Dim. of πῆχυς, Anon. ap. Suid.

children.definition: cubit-measure, Sm. Ez. 43.13.
measuring by the cubit, Ostr.Bodl. i 90 (ii B.C.), PTeb. 164.14 ( ii B.C., pl.), Sm., al. l.c., Judeich Altertümer von Hierapolis No. 262.
a cubit long, IG 1(2).88.8, Hdt. 2.48, 78, Hp. Fract. 8, Pl. Phd. 96e, Plb. 6.23.12, etc.; τὸ π. Plot. 6.3.21.
Poll. 7.53.
A.R. 3.1207 ; π. χρόνος ‘but a span’, Mimn. 2.3 ; ἐρετμὰ πήχυιον προὔχοντα projecting for the space of a cubit, A.R. 1.379 (wrongly expld. as = τροπωτήρ by EM 671.8).
take in oneʼs arms, embrace, A.R. 4.972, Nonn. D. 25.177 ; τινὰ ἀγοστῷ ib. 3.340 : more freq. in Med., χείρεσσι AP 12.121 ( Rhian.), Opp. H. 4.286, Nonn. D. 9.30 ; ἀγοστῷ ib. 14.152.

definition: πῆχυς ( Aeol. πᾶχυς Alc. 33), ὁ, gen. πήχεος Hp. Fract. 2, al., Hdt. 1.178, Pl. Alc. 1.126d, Arist. Mir. 813a10, LXX Ex. 25.9, al., Plb. 10.44.2, Ph. Bel. 73.42, πήχεως Arist. HA 606a14 ( v.l. - εος), PCair.Zen. 484.10 (iii B.C.), πήχως (condemned by Phryn. 222) corrected to πήχεος PCair.Zen. 665.1 (iii B. C.) : gen. pl. πήχεων IG 1(2).314.39, 22.1673.15, PCair.Zen. 353.10 (iii B. C.); later contr. πηχῶν X. An. 4.7.16 codd., Arist. Pol. 1302b37, PCair.Zen. 54.4 (iii B. C.), PStrassb. 85.20 (ii B. C.), Phld. Sign. 2, Phryn. 222, Moer. p.327P.:—

children.definition: forearm, from wrist to elbow, Hp. Fract. 2, 3, al., Poll. 2.140 ; opp. βραχίων, Pl. Ti. 75a, X. Eq. 12.5: in Poets, generally, arm, ἀμφὶ δʼ ἑὸν φίλον υἱὸν ἐχεύατο πήχεε λευκώ Il. 5.314, cf. Od. 17.38, 23.240 ; λευκὸν ἀντείνασα π. B. Fr. 13.4, cf. E. Or. 1466 (lyr.) ; λαιὸν ἔπαιρε π. Id. Heracl. 728.

data.quote: ἀμφὶ δʼ ἑὸν φίλον υἱὸν ἐχεύατο πήχεε λευκώ

children.definition: ulna, Ruf. Onom. 80, Gal. UP 2.2, Sor. Fract. 20.

children.label: II
children.definition: centrepiece, which joined the two horns of the bow, τόν ῥʼ [ὀϊστὸν] ἐπὶ πήχει ἑλὼν ἕλκεν νευρήν Od. 21.419 ; ὁ δὲ τόξου πῆχυν ἄνελκε Il. 11.375, 13.583.

data.quote: τόν ῥʼ [ὀϊστὸν] ἐπὶ πήχει ἑλὼν ἕλκεν νευρήν

children.label: III
children.definition: horns of the lyre, opp. ζυγόν (the bridge), Hdt. 4.192 ; πήχεις ἐναρμόσας καὶ ζυγώσας Luc. DDeor. 11[7].4.
crosspiece or bridge in which the horns were fitted, ArtemoHist. 12.

children.label: V
children.definition: distance from the point of the elbow to that of the middle finger, = 6 παλασταί = 24 δάκτυλοι, Poll. 2.158 ; π. μέτριος Hdt. 1.178 ; π. ἰδιωτικός, κοινός, Sch. Luc. Cat. 16 ; but π. βασιλήϊος, = 27 δάκτυλοι, Hdt. 1.178, 7.117 ; ὁ Αἰγύπτιος π. τυγχάνει ἴσος ἐὼν τῷ Σαμίῳ Id. 2.168, cf. Luc. l.c. ; for later measurements, Hero Deff. 131, Geom. 4.2, al.

data.quote: ὁ Αἰγύπτιος π. τυγχάνει ἴσος ἐὼν τῷ Σαμίῳ

children.definition: cubit-rule, as we say ‘foot-rule’, Ar. Ra. 799, Gal. 1.47 ; π. ἀκαμπής AP 6.204 ( Leon.) ; as epith. of Nemesis, APl. 16.223, 224.
πήχυιος), Ev.Matt. 6.27 ; κατὰ πῆχυν little by little, Marin. Procl. 26.

children.label: VI
children.definition: πήχεις, οἱ, the cubits (of inundation), represented in pictures as children one cubit high playing round the Nile, Luc. Rh.Pr. 6, Philostr. Im. 1.5. (Cf. Skt. bāhú-, Avest. bāzu- (masc.) ‘arm’, ONorse bógr ‘shoulder’.)

definition: πιάζω, Dor. and later Att. for πιέζω (q. v.).

πιαίνω, fut. πιᾰνῶ A. Th. 587 : aor. ἐπίᾱνα Id. Ag. 276, Hp. Mul. 1.47 ; poet. πίᾱνα Pi. N. 9.23 ; later ἐπίηνα D.L. 1.83 :— Pass., fut. πιανθήσομαι LXX Ps. 64(65).12 : aor. ἐπιάνθην Anan. 5.9, Theoc. 17.126, ( κατ-) Ael. NA 2.13 ; but aor. inf. συμ-πιασθῆναι Hp. Epid. 7.68 (s. v.l.): pf. πεπίασμαι ( κατα-) Pl. Lg. 807b, cf. Ael. NA 13.25 : ( πίων) :

children.definition: fatten, τὸ σῶμα Hp. l.c.; ἡ γῆ π. τὰ βοτά E. Cyc. 333 ; [ τὰς ὗς] Arist. HA 603b27 ; π. χθόνα enrich the soil, of a dead man, A. Th. 587 ; σώμασι πίαναν καπνόν, of bodies being burnt, Pi. l.c.:— Pass., to be or become fat, Semon. 7.6, Pl. Lg. 807a, Arist. HA 520b7, etc.; π. ὁ στάχυς Theoc. 10.47.
increase, enlarge, πλοῦτον Pi. P. 4.150 (where ῐ); μυχοὺς πόλεως Xenoph. 2.22.

make wanton, ἀλλʼ ἦ σʼ ἐπίανέν τις ἄπτερος φάτις; A. Ag. 276 ; π. τὰ πάθη Porph. Abst. 1.34 :— Pass., wax fat and wanton, πρᾶσσε, πιαίνου A. Ag. 1669 (anap.) ; ἔχθεσιν πιαίνεσθαι batten on quarrels, Pi. P. 2.56 ; φθόνῳ π. B. 3.68.
cherish, cheer, ἵππον . . π. ὁ τοῦ δεσπότου ὀφθαλμός Anon. ap. Arist. Oec. 1345a3 ; π. ἑὴν φρένα Opp. H. 5.372 ; μέλος ib. 620 ; μάστακα π. χείλεος εὐαφίῃ AP 5.293.16 ( Agath.).—Rare in Prose.

data.quote: ἵππον . . π. ὁ τοῦ δεσπότου ὀφθαλμός

definition: πιαλέος, α, ον, Ion., poet., and late Prose for πίων, Hp. Mul. 1.17, AP 6.190 ( Gaet.), 299 ( Phan.), Artem. 1.46, Opp. C. 1.86, etc.;

children.definition: rich, πόσις Nic. Al 360, cf. Nonn. D. 3.146, al.

definition: πίαλος, v.l. for σίαλος in Hp. Mul. 2.133 ; but,

children.definition: Hsch.
fattening : τὰ π. fattening food, Hp. Loc.Hom. 28.
= foreg., Apollon. Lex. s.v. πίονα ἔργα.

definition: πῖαρ, τό, only nom. and acc. (exc. dat. πίαρι Suid.) : ( πίων) :—

children.definition: fat, Ep. and Ion. word, βοῶν ἐκ πῖαρ ἑλέσθαι Il. 11.550 ; of men, Hp. Nat.Puer. 21.

children.label: b
children.definition: any fatty substance, π. ἐλαίης A.R. 4.1133 ; π. μελιηδές prob. cream, AP 9.224 ( Crin.), cf. Sol. 36.21 ( πῦαρ Pap. Arist. Ath.); thick juice from trees, Hp. Nat.Puer. 26; of the fig, Id. Mul. 2.205, Ulc. 15 ; richness of soil, ἐπεὶ μάλα π. ὑπʼ οὖδας Od. 9.135, cf. h.Ap. 60 ; ἐσθλῆς ἀρούρης π. ἔγκληρον χθονός Lyc. 1060, cf. AP 9.555 ( Crin.).
cream, choicest part of a thing, h.Ven. 30.

fat, rich, τὸ πιαρόν Hp. Nat.Puer. 21 ( p.514 L., sed leg. τὸ πῖαρ, cf. p.512) :— πιαρά and πιερά are prob. ff. ll. for πίειρα in ib. 22, Arist. Pr. 892b33, and πίεραι, πιεραῖς ff. ll. for πίειραι, πιείραις in Hp. Aër. 21, Ath.Med. ap. Orib. 1.2.4.
that which makes fat, of a river, π. Βοιωτῶν χθονί bringing fatness and riches to . . , A. Pers. 806.

definition: πίασμα [ῐ] (B), ατος, τό, Dor. and later Gr. for πίεσμα (q.v.).

children.definition: fatness, fat, Ael. NA 13.25.
TAM 2.385 ( Xanthus), 611 ( Tlos) ; cf. πινάτρα.
= Lat. privatus, Edict.Diocl. 7.76.
lizard, = χαλκίς, Hsch. πίγγαν· νεοσσίον, Amerias ap. Hsch.
= Lat. pincerna, cupbearer, PLond. 5.1656.3 (iv A. D.).
growing at or about a spring, βοτάναι Hp. Ep. 16.
full of springs, Hegesin. ap. Paus. 9.29.1 ; gushing, λιβάς E. Andr. 116 (eleg.).
full of springs, τόποι Plu. Aem. 14 ; π. σάρξ, of a womanʼs breasts, Id. Am. prol. 2.496a.

spring, fountain, μάχεσθον π. ἀμφʼ ὀλίγης Il. 16.825, cf. Theoc. 7.142, Call. Ap. 112, etc.; [ γῆ] ἔπυδρος πίδαξι Hdt. 4.198 ; οὐρειᾶν πιδάκων . . ῥοαῖς E. Andr. 285 (lyr.) ; π. ῥωγός AP 6.238 ( Apollonid.), cf. 158 (Tull. Sab.), 334 ( Leon.), etc.
Arist. Mete. 349b34, Hsch., Choerob. in An.Ox. 2.249; prob. cj. in Hp. Epid. 5.16, Theoc. 8.42.
rich in springs, Ἴδη Il. 11.183.
Hsch. ( πηδ- cod.).
gush forth, AP 9.322 ( Leon.), 10.13 ( Satyr.); ὀλίγον καὶ πονηρὸν ἐπίδυε [τὸ ποτόν] Plu. Aem. 14, cf. Antig. Mir. 144: — Med., Nic. Th. 302. [ ῡ exc. in Nic. l.c.]

definition: πιέζω, impf. ἐπίεζον, Ep. πίεζον Od. 12.174, etc.: fut. πιέσω Diph. 18.3; Ep. πιέσσω Nonn. D. 4.146: aor. ἐπίεσα Hp. Fract. 6, Hdt. 9.63, Th. 2.52, etc. (but subj. πιέξῃς Hp. Fract. 5, inf. πιέξαι IG 42(1).123.116 ( Epid., iv B.C.), part. πιέξας (v.l. πιάξας) Nic. Al. 224): pf. πεπίεκα Demetr.Lac. Herc. 1012.44 :— Pass., fut. πιεσθήσομαι Gal. 11.317 ( δια-), Heliod ap. Orib. 10.18.15: aor. ἐπιέσθην Od. 8.336, Sol. 13.37, Hdt. 4.11, etc.; ἐπιέχθην Hp. Fract. 5, etc.: pf. πεπίεσμαι Arist. Mu. 392b33, Procl. Hyp. 5.49, cj. in Alciphr. 3.55. etc.; πεπίεγμαι Hp. Fract. 5.—From πῐεζέω we have πιεζέουσι v.l. in Id. Fract. 31 : impf. πιέζευν v.l. in Od. 12.174, 196; part. πιεζεῦντα Hp. Off. 25, Fract. 9, πιεζεῦσαν Herod. 8.47 :— Pass., part. πιεζεύμενος Hdt. 3.146, 6.108, 8.142 (always with v.l. - όμενος), Hp. Nat.Puer. 21, πιεζούμενος Plb. 3.74.2; imper. πιεζείσθω IG 4.364.7 ( Corinth, iv A.D.): impf. ἐπιεζοῦντο Plb. 11.33.3; so in later Gr., as Plu. Thes. 6, Alc. 2, etc.; Dor., Aeol., and later Gr. πῐάζω Alcm. 44, Alc. 148: aor. 1 ἐπίᾰσα LXX Ca. 2.15, Ev.Jo. 8.20; ἐπίαξα Theoc. 4.35, ( ἀμφ-) Ep. 6.4: Pass., fut. πιασθήσομαι LXX Si. 23.21 : aor. ἐπιάσθην Apoc. 19.20 : pf. πεπίασμαι POxy. 812 (i B. C.), Dsc. 1.15, Hippiatr. 34 :—

children.definition: press tight, squeeze, χειρὶ ἑλὼν ἐπίεζε βραχίονα Il. 16.510, cf. Hes. Op. 497; ἀστεμφέως ἐχέμεν μᾶλλόν τε π. Od. 4.419; μʼ ἐν δεσμοῖσι δέον μᾶλλόν τε πίεζον 12.196, cf. 164; π. τὰ χείλεα compress them, Hp. VM 22; ῥύγχος εἰς ὄξος π. Axionic. 8.5 ; π. τοὺς ὑπευθύνους squeezing them (like figs), to try if they are ripe, Ar. Eq. 259 ; σφόδρα π. αὐτοῦ τὸν πόδα Pl. Phd. 117e ; π. [τὴν δεξιὰν] ἐμπαθῶς Plb. 31.24.9 : abs., X. Mem. 3.10.13, Arist. Rh. 1361b17 :— Pass., to be pressed tight, ἐν δεσμοῖς Od. 8.336, cf. Hp. Fract. 25, al.; of wrestlers, Plu. Alc. 2; πιέζεται ὅσα πόρους ἔχει κενούς are compressible, Arist. Mete. 386b1.

data.quote: μʼ ἐν δεσμοῖσι δέον μᾶλλόν τε πίεζον

children.label: II
children.definition: press or weigh down, of a heavy weight, Σικελία αὐτοῦ π. στέρνα Pi. P. 1.19, cf. Ar. Pax 1032 :—and in Pass., ὁ δʼ ὦμος . . πιέζεται Id. Ra. 30, cf. X. Cyr. 7.5.11 : metaph., oppress, distress, π. τινὰ ἡ δαπάνη Hdt. 5.35 ; λιμός A. Ch. 250 ; καὶ πρὸς π. χρημάτων ἀχηνία (Abresch for προσπιέζει) ib. 301 ; συμφορὰ δʼἑτέρους ἑτέρα π. E. Alc. 894 (lyr.); αὐχμὸς π. τὰς ἀμπέλους Ar. Nu. 1120 ; π. ἡ ἀνάγκη ib. 437, cf. Th. 2.52 :—freq. in Pass., ὑπὸ νούσοισι Sol. 13.37 ; ὑπὸ λιμοῦ Th. 1.126 ; πολέμῳ Hdt. 4.11, 6.34 ; τῇ νούσῳ Pherecyd. ap. D.L. 1.122, cf. Th. 7.47 ; ταῖς εἰσφοραῖς Lys. 28.3; ταῖς συμφοραῖς X. Cyr. 7.2.20; σπάνει σίτου Id. HG 5.4.56, etc.: abs., Hdt. 7.121, etc.; of a river, to be exhausted from the heat of the sun, Id. 2.25.
press hard, of a victorious army, τοὺς ἐναντίους Id. 9.63 :— Pass., τὴν πιεζομένην μάλιστα τῶν μοιρέων ib. 60; εἴ πῃ πιέζοιντο Th. 1.49, cf. X. HG 2.4.34 ; ὑπό τινων ib. 7.1.43.

bear hardly upon, τινα Pl. Cra. 409a; τῷ λόγῳ Plu. Alc. 6; ὑπὸ τῶν ἐλέγχων πιέζεσθαι Phld. D. 3.8; of a point in the argument, hold fast to, Pl. Lg. 965d; press it, Plb. 3.21.3, Demetr.Lac. l.c., etc.; lay stress on, Plu. Aud.poet. 2.31e: c. dat., insist upon, τοῖσι περιπάτοισι Hp. Insomn. 88.

children.label: b
children.definition: determine precisely, ἀποστήματα Procl. Hyp. 5.19, cf. 49 ( Pass.); π. δεῖ πῶς ἓν ἐκεῖνο καὶ ἕτερον Porph. Sent. 36.

data.quote: π. δεῖ πῶς ἓν ἐκεῖνο καὶ ἕτερον

children.definition: repress, stifle, ἐν θυμῷ χόλον Pi. O. 6.37; τὸν τῦφον Plu. Alc. 4.
outweigh, τἀγαθῷ τὸ δυστυχές E. Hipp. 637, cf. Supp. 249 (s. v.l.).

children.label: III
children.definition: lay hold of, ταῦρον . . πιάξας τᾶς ὁπλᾶς by the hoof, Theoc. 4.35; αὐτὸν τῆς χειρός Act.Ap. 3.7, cf. Ev.Jo. 7.30, etc.

definition: πίειρα [ ῑ], ἡ, fem. of πίων,

children.definition: fat, rich, mostly of land, ἄρουρα π. Il. 18.541. Od. 2.328, etc.; γαῖα 19.173; χθών Sol. ap. Arist. Ath. 12.3, cf. Pl. Criti. 111b, Thphr. HP 8.6.2; Σικελία Pi. N. 1.15; δαὶς π. rich, plenteous meal, Il. 19.180; of wood, resinous, juicy, S. Tr. 766, cf. Hp. Nat.Puer. 26; of doves, plump, Arist. HA 600a23. (Cf. Skt. pīívarī, fem. of pīívā, v. πίων.)
Hp. Fract. 6, Art. 63, Aret. CD 1.3 (pl.).

Pieria, in the S.W. of Macedonia, Il. 14.226, Od. 5.50, Hes. Th. 53. Adv. Πῑερίηθεν, from Pieria, Id. Op. 1, h.Merc. 85: Πῑερίδες, αἱ, Pierides, name of the Muses, as haunting Pieria, Hes. Sc. 206, Pi. O. 10(11).96, P. 1.14, etc.: Adj. Πῑερικός, ή, όν, Hdt. 4.195, etc.
pressing, Gloss.
squeezing, compression, Arist. PA 687b11 (pl.), Mete. 387a16; pinching, ποδῶν Aret. CA 1.2; pressure, close contact, Gal. 18(2).398.

definition: πίεσμα, ατος, Dor. and later Gr. πίασμα, τό,

children.definition: anything pressed:
pulpy mass left after pressing, pomace, μυροβαλάνου Gal. 10.911, Gp. 20.28 : pl., of cakes of olive-pulp, PSI 9.1030.11 ( ii A. D., in form πιάσματα).
juice pressed out, Dsc. 1.78.

children.label: II
children.definition: Eub. 75.11 ( πιάσματι codd. Ath.), cf. AP 12.41 ( Mel.).
Hp. Nat.Puer. 21 (v.l. for ἐκπ-), Eust. 1181.63 : metaph., in pl., constraint, pressure of circumstances, Epicur. Nat. 28.3.
to be pressed, Hp. Fract. 25.

children.label: II
children.definition: πιεστέον one must squeeze, press, τὴν κεφαλήν Orib. Fr. 48.
squeezer : press, IG 2(2).1672.304 (pl.), Dsc. 4.64 ( v.l. πιαστ-), Gal. 13.1044, Aët. 12.55.
pressing, squeezing, πιαστήρια ὄργανα Heliod. ap. Orib. 49.4.68.

children.label: II
children.definition: πιεστήριον, τό, press, Dsc. 4.75; Dor. πιαστήριον Gloss.
compressible, Arist. Mete. 385a15, Thphr. Lass. 8.

definition: πιήεις, εσσα, εν, poet. for πίων, AP 6.300 ( Leon.).
πιθάκνη, ἡ, Att. φῐδάκνη Moer. p.392P., Phot., Lacon. πῐσάκνα Hsch.: ( πίθος) :—

children.definition: cask or jar, Ar. Pl. 546, Ion Trag. 10, BCH 50.214 ( Thasos, v B.C.); used for storing figs, etc., D. 30.28, Pl.Com. 114, Thphr. Sign. 49, OGI 483.149 ( Pergam., ii A.D.); οἰκεῖν ἐν ταῖς φιδάκναις live in casks, as the poorer Athenians were forced to do during the Peloponn. war, Ar. Eq. 792; π. ἰατρική a medicine- jar, Gal. 19.115, cf. UP 4.3 :—also πῐθακνίς, ίδος, ἡ, Att. φῐδακνίς, Poll. 10.74, 131; Dim. πῐθάκνιον, τό, Eub. 132, Hyp. Fr. 265, Luc. Hist.Conscr. 4, etc. ( Dim. of πίθος, as πολίχνη of πόλις, Sch. Ar. Eq. l.c.)

definition: πίθακος, Dor. for πίθηκος; also in Sammelb. 2629 ( Naucratis).

children.definition: use probable arguments, Arist. EN 1094b26, D.S. 1.39: — Med., Dam. Pr. 405, Sch. E. Or. 424 :— Pass., Epicur. Ep. 2p.36U., Orib. 49.22.22.
probable argument, Sch. E. Hec. 258.
use of probable arguments, opp. demonstration ( ἀπόδειξις), Pl. Tht. 162e, cf. Ep.Col. 2.4, Gal. 17(1).619.
art of using probable or specious arguments, Arr. Epict. 1.8.7.
speaking persuasively, Sch. Ar. Ra. 91.
sharpen the wits of one, Hsch. s.v. κομψεύεται.

definition: πιθανός, ή, όν, ( πείθω) of persons,

children.definition: persuasive, plausible, esp. of popular speakers, πιθανώτατος τοῖς πολλοῖς Th. 6.35 ; τῷ δήμῳ παρὰ πολὺ . . -ώτατος, of Cleon, Id. 3.36, cf. 4.21; ἐν ὄχλῳ π. Pl. Grg. 458e; -ώτατος πάντων ἀνθρώπων D. 37.48; -ώτεροι οἱ ἀπαίδευτοι τῶν πεπαιδευμένων ἐν τοῖς ὄχλοις Arist. Rh. 1395b27; -ώτατοι οἱ ἐν τοῖς πάθεσιν Id. Po. 1455a30; π. καὶ πανοῦργος Plu. Aud.poet. 2.26a; π. συνταγματάρχης Luc. Bacch. 2 : c. inf., -ώτατοι λέγειν Pl. Grg. 479c; π. περιβαλεῖν τινα κακῷ apt at . . , E. Or. 906; πιθανώτατος στρατηγῆσαί τε καὶ προσαγαγέσθαι App. Hisp. 15, etc.: with a Prep., π. ἐς στρατηγίαν, ἐς ἐνέδρας, Id. Mith. 51, Pun. 108, etc.

data.quote: -ώτεροι οἱ ἀπαίδευτοι τῶν πεπαιδευμένων ἐν τοῖς ὄχλοις

children.definition: plausible, Ar. Th. 464 (lyr.); λέγων πιθανώτατʼ Id. Eq. 629; λόγος, φωναὶ π., Pl. Phd. 88d, R. 568c; λόγοι θαυμασίως ὡς π. D. 35.16; τὸ περὶ λόγους π., = πιθανότης, Pl. Tht. 178e : freq. in Arist. Rh., as 1356b26, 1403b20; μόνον ἐφρόντισαν τοῦ π. τοῦ πρὸς αὑτούς Id. Metaph. 1000a10.

data.quote: μόνον ἐφρόντισαν τοῦ π. τοῦ πρὸς αὑτούς

children.definition: winning, plausible, τὸ -ώτατον ἦθος X. Mem. 3.10.3; τὸ π. ἰσχὺν τῆς ἀληθείας ἔχει μείζω Men. 622 codd. Stob.; οὐ π. ἔσχεν ὄχλῳ τὸ ἦθος Plu. Phoc. 3.

data.quote: τὸ π. ἰσχὺν τῆς ἀληθείας ἔχει μείζω
οὐ π. ἔσχεν ὄχλῳ τὸ ἦθος

children.definition: plausible, specious, credible, λόγος πιθανώτατος Hdt. 1.214, cf. 2.123; π. τινί Pl. Lg. 677a: c. inf., πιστεύεσθαι πιθανά ib. 782d; πιθανόν [ἐστι] c. inf., it is probable that . . , Arist. Top. 151a29.
producing illusion, true to nature, X. Mem. 3.10.7 ( Comp.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., easy to persuade, credulous, A. Ag. 485 (lyr.), Pl. Grg. 493a.
obedient, docile, X. Cyr. 2.2.10, Oec. 13.9 ( Comp.).

children.label: III
children.definition: Adv. - νῶς persuasively, plausibly, Ar. Th. 268, Pl. Phdr. 269c, al. : Comp. -ώτερον Id. Phd. 63b, Grg. 456c, Arist. EN 1096b5.
persuasiveness, plausibility, of persons, Plb. 22.20.2, Plu. Stoic.rep. 2.1040b (pl.).

Pl. Lg. 839d, Cra. 402a; π. τινὰ ἔχει ὁ λόγος Arist. EN 1097a4, cf. Phld. Rh. 1.209 S. ; πιθανότητας ἐλάμβανε κατὰ τῶν ἀνθρώπων provided himself with plausible charges against . . , Plb. 27.15.9, cf. 12.26c. 2, Ph. 1.94 (pl.).
faculty of persuasion, Them. Or. 26.330a.
having the faculty of persuasion, Numen. ap. Eus. PE 14.5; τέχνη art of persuasion, Pl. Sph. 222c sq.
making probable, τῶν ἀπιθάνων Sch.Hermog. in Rh. 7.218 W.
make probable, Arist. Rh. 1408a19.
Dim. of πίθος, Hsch. s.v. φιδάκνη, EM 671.46.

definition: πιθεών, ῶνος, ὁ, later form of πιθών (q.v.), D.S. 13.83, AP 9.403 ( Maec.), Gp. 6.12.3.

children.definition: of an ape, ape-like, Gal. 2.386, UP 3.8, Suid.
Ael. NA 6.26.
young ape, Ael. NA 7.47.
play the ape, of flatterers, Lib. Ep. 424.1, 1397.5 :— Med., Sch.rec. D. 18.242 (viii p.325 Dindorf) : barbarous form ἐπιτήκιζι or ἐπιτήκιζε cj. for ἐπιθηκίζει in Ar. Th. 1133.
Dim. of πίθηκος, Lat. pithecium Plaut. Mil. 989.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ath.Mech. 32.11.

children.label: III
children.definition: Apul. Herb. 86.
playing the ape, playing monkey-tricks, Ar. Eq. 887, M.Ant. 9.37.
ape-like, Arist. HA 498b15, Gal. 2.545.
ape-shaped, Lyc. 1000, Sor. 1.39.
ape, monkey, Archil. 89.3, 91, S. Ichn. 122, Ar. Ach. 120, Arist. HA 502a17 : as fem., πίθηκος μήτηρ Babr. 56; πίθηκον ἐνδυομένην putting on an apeʼs form, Pl. R. 620c; cf. πιθήκη.
jackanapes, Ar. Ach. 907, Av. 440, Ra. 708, etc. ; αὐτοτραγικὸς π., of Aeschines, D. 18.242.

ἀντὶ λέοντος π. γίγνεσθαι Pl. R. 590b; ὑπὸ τῇ λεοντῇ πίθηκον περιστέλλειν Luc. Philops. 5; π. ἐν πορφύρᾳ ‘borrowed plumes’, Diogenian. 7.94; ἐν πιθήκοις ὄντα δεῖ εἶναι π. ‘in Rome we do as the Romans do’, Apollod.Com. 1.3 ; ὄνος ἐν πιθήκοις ‘parmi les aveugles le borgne est roi’, Men. 402.8.
dwarf, Suid.

children.label: II
children.definition: ζῷον σελαχῶδες, Ael. NA 12.27.

definition: Πιθηκοῦσσαι (as if from πιθηκόεις) (sc. νῆσοι), ῶν, αἱ,

children.definition: Ape-islands, off the coast of Campania, Arist. Mir. 833a14, Str. 1.3.10, etc.; one of them being specially named Πιθηκοῦσσα, Id. 1.3.19; Πιθήκινοι νῆσοι, v.l. in Harp.
eat apeʼs flesh, Hdt. 4.194.
branded with the mark of an ape, Luc. Pisc. 47.
Arist. Phgn. 812a9, Ael. NA 12.27.
dwarf, Procop. Goth. 4.24.

children.label: II
children.definition: Aesop. 43b, Zonar.; = μιμώ, Suid.
πῖθι, v. πίνω.
jar-shaped comet, Seneca QN 1.14, Phlp. in Mete. 92.34 :—written πιθείας, Procl. Par.Ptol. 131.

definition: πιθίσκος, ὁ, Dim. of πίθος, in pl., = Lat. Doliola, prob. l. in Plu. Cam. 20.

children.definition: corn poppy, Papaver Rhoeas, Dsc. 4.64.
cask-shaped, σχῆμα Hero Stereom. 2.22.

festival at the opening of casks of new wine, held at the Anthesteria, Plu. QConv. 2.655e, 735e :—later πῐθοιγία, ἡ, Eust. 1363.26 ; πῐθοιγὶς ἠώς, the morning of this festival, Call. Aet. 1.1.1 [Fr. 178.1 Pf.]; Πῐθοιγιών, ῶνος, ὁ, month in which the festival took place, prob. in IG 12(8).645 (Peparethus, -κιών lapis).
Ar. Eq. 789.

large wine-jar, Il. 24.527, Od. 2.340, 23.305, Hes. Op. 98, 368, IG 1(2).328.2, etc. : usu. of earthenware, π. κεράμινοι Hdt. 3.96, cf. Ar. Pax 703, Pl. La. 187b, Grg. 493a; π. ἀργύρεοι, sent by Croesus to Delphi, Hdt. 1.51; but π. ξύλινοι casks, Str. 5.1.12, cf. Hdn. 8.4.5.

εἰς τὸν τετρημένον π. ἀντλεῖν, of the task of the Danaids, i.e. of labour in vain, X. Oec. 7.40, cf. Philetaer. 18.5, Luc. Herm. 61, DMort. 21[11].4; applied to insatiable appetites, Pl. Grg. 493b; to largesses made by demagogues, Arist. Pol. 1320a32, cf. Oec. 1344b25; ἐκ πίθω ἀντλεῖς you have wine by the caskful, i.e. your purse is deep, Theoc. 10.13; ἐν πίθῳ ἡ κεραμεία γιγνομένη ‘trying to run before you can walk’, Pl. La. 187b, cf. Grg. 514e, Ar. Fr. 469; ζωὴ πίθου a Cynicʼs life, like that of Diogenes, Zen. 4.14; π. φρενῶν a cask full of wit, Men. Mon. 240 ( = IG 14.699), expld. with ref. to Diogenes by Eust. 1363.40.

children.label: II
children.definition: Arist. Mu. 395b12, Ptol. Tetr. 90. (Cf. Lat. fidelia.)

definition: πιθόω, Boeot. for πείθω, IG 7.3172.58 (Orchom. Boeot., iii B.C.).

children.definition: like a jar or cask, βόθυνος Arist. HA 558a8.
little ape, Babr. 56.4: καλὸς π. παρὰ παισίν Pi. P. 2.72, cf. Sostrat. ap. Eust. 1665.53.
cellar, Pherecr. 138, Eup. 111, IG ΙΙ(2).287 A 168 ( Delos, iii B.C.), 12(5).872.52 ( Tenos, iii B.C.(?)); cf. πιθεών.

definition: πιθών, aor. 2 part. of πείθω, Pi. P. 3.28.

children.definition: Hp. Mul. 1.63, Arist. Fr. 636, Aret. CA 1.1, Gal. 19.131 : Phrygian acc. to Erot.
antidote, ‘higry-pigry’ (i.e. ἱερὰ π.), Alex.Trall. 7.6, Febr. 6.
taste bitter, ib. 2.51, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: π. τὸν λόγον τῇ κακίᾳ Epict. Gnom. 22.
make sharp or keen, esp. to the taste, π. τὴν κοιλίαν make it bitter, Apoc. 10.9 :— Pass., τὸ στόμα πικραίνεται Hp. Acut. 30: opp. γλυκαίνεσθαι, Arist. Ph. 244b20.

embitter, irritate, τὴν ψυχήν LXX Jb. 27.2; τὴν ἀκοήν affect it harshly, opp. γλυκαίνω, D.H. Comp. 12, 15; make harsh, νόμους cj. in A. Eu. 693 :— Pass., to be exasperated, embittered, Pl. Lg. 731d, Theoc. 5.120; ὁ ζωγράφος πονεῖ τι καὶ π. vexes himself, Antiph. 144.3; π. ἐπί τισι LXX Ex. 16.20; ἔν τισι ib. Ru. 1.20; also ἐπικράνθη μοι it grieved me, ib. 13.
make harsh or rugged, διάλεκτον D.H. Dem. 55, cf. 34.
disposed to bitterness. Adv. -κῶς, διατίθεσθαι S.E. M. 7.367.
bitterness : bitter feeling, ψυχῆς LXX Ez. 27.31 : pl., Ph. 1.441 :—written πικραμμός, Aq. Jb. 3.5.
bitterness:
Thphr. CP 6.10.7, Od. 32, LXX Je. 15.17, Placit. 3.16.2, Dsc. 1.61, etc.

τὴν ἀπὸ τῆς ψυχῆς π. D. 21.204, cf. 25.84, Ep. 3.33, Arist. VV 1251a4, Phld. Ir. p.56W.; ἡ ἐπὶ τοῖς γεγονόσι π. Plb. 15.4.11 ; πρὸς τὸν δῆμον Plu. Cor. 15 ; ἡ ἐν τοῖς λόγοις π. D.S. 16.88 ; λόγος π. ἔχων μεμιγμένην χάριτι Plu. Lyc. 19.
ἡ τοῦ καιροῦ π. BGU 417.5 (ii/iii A. D.).
endive, Cichorium Endivia, Ps.- Dsc. 2.132, Gp. 12.1.
somewhat bitter, σῦκα Ath. 3.78a.
to be or taste bitter, Str. 11.2.17, Archig. ap. Orib. 8.1.37 ; π. ἐν τῇ γεύσει Dsc. 1.20.
ox-tongue, Helminthia sepioides, Arist. HA 12a30, Thphr. HP 7.11.4.

children.label: II
children.definition: sour soil, Sammelb. 6797.12 (iii B. C.), prob. in PCair.Zen. 517.17, 728.3, 8 (iii B.C.).
attaining a bitter kind of marriage (cf. πικρός III), Od. 1.266, al., Hld. 5.30, 7.28.
of sharp or bitter tongue, ἀραί A. Th. 787 (lyr.).
bearing bitter fruit, ἀνδροκτασία A. Th. 693 (lyr.).
bitterness of language, Arist. VV 1251a9.
speaking bitter things, γλῶσσα prob. in Epigr.Gr. 288c4 ( Cyprus).
of the bitter lotus, σπέρμα Gal. 14.159.
causing bitterness, Eust. 820.49 ; ἔχις Sch. Opp. H. 1.559.

definition: πικρός, ά, όν, poet. also ός, όν Od. 4.406 :—prop.

children.definition: pointed, sharp, keen, ὀϊστός Il. 4.118, al.; βέλεμνα 22.206; γλωχίς S. Tr. 681 : metaph., γλώσσης πικροῖς κέντροισι E. HF 1288.

children.label: II
children.definition: sharp to the sense:

pungent, ῥίζα Il. 11.846; ἅλμη Od. 5.323; δάκρυον (v.l. for πυκνόν) 4.153; of salt water, opp. γλυκύς, Hdt. 4.52, cf. 7.35; ἁλμυρὸς καὶ π. Pl. Lg. 705a; πριγλία π. PCair.Zen. 82.8 (iii B.C.); ἀπʼ ὄμφακος πικρᾶς A. Ag. 970; ὑγρότης π., opp. ὀξεῖα, Meno Iatr. 5.13; also of smell, pungent, Od. 4.406; πικρὸν ὀδωδώς Alciphr. 3.59. (This sense prevails in the derived and compd. words.)
sharp, keen, ὠδῖνες Il. 11.271, S. Tr. 41.
piercing, shrill, οἰμωγά Id. Ph. 189 (lyr.); φθόγγος Id. OC 1610; γόοι, ὄδυρμα, E. Ph. 883, Tr. 1227 (lyr.); πικροτάτη ὄψ Ar. Pax 805 (lyr.).

bitter, esp. of what yields pain instead of expected pleasure, freq. in threats, μὴ τάχα πικρὴν Αἴγυπτον καὶ Κύπρον ἵκηαι (v.l. ἴδηαι) Od. 17.448, cf. Ar. Av. 1045, Th. 883 (lyr.), E. Med. 399, IA 955, Ba. 357, Cyc. 589; π. Σίγειον κατηγόμην S. Ph. 355; τὸ πὰρ δίκαν γλυκὺ πικροτάτα μένει τελευτά Pi. I. 7(6).48, cf. A. Ag. 745 (lyr.) ; τιμωρία, ἀγῶνες, Id. Pers. 473, S. Aj. 1239 ; δύαι, χεῖμα, A. Pr. 180 (lyr.), Ag. 198 (lyr.) ; πικρότερʼ ἀχέων Id. Supp. 875 (lyr.); λόγοι E. Hel. 481 ; πικροτάτου χρυσοῦ φύλαξ Id. Hec. 772 ; τὸ δὴ λεγόμενον γλυκὺ πικρῷ μεμειγμένον Pl. Phlb. 46c ; ἔχει τι τὸ π. τῆς γεωργίας γλυκύ Men. 795 : c. inf., μὴ λίαν πικρὸν εἰπεῖν ᾖ D. 1.26.

data.quote: τὸ πὰρ δίκαν γλυκὺ πικροτάτα μένει τελευτά
τὸ δὴ λεγόμενον γλυκὺ πικρῷ μεμειγμένον
ἔχει τι τὸ π. τῆς γεωργίας γλυκύ

children.definition: Sapph. Supp. 4.1 ( Comp.) ; γλυκὺν ὧδε φίλοις ἐχθροῖσι δὲ π. Sol. 13.5, cf. Thgn. 301, A. Ch. 234, Eu. 152 (lyr.), etc. ; ἔς τινας Hdt. 1.123 : abs., A. Pr. 739, Th 940 (lyr.); π. θεοῖς hateful to them, S. Ph. 254; π. πολίταις E. Med. 224, cf. Supp. 1222 ; ἐμοὶ π. τέθνηκεν ἢ κείνοις γλυκύς his death is matter of sorrow to me, S. Aj. 966 ; δαίμων π., of untimely death (Lat. acerbus), IG 3.1338.

data.quote: γλυκὺν ὧδε φίλοις ἐχθροῖσι δὲ π.

children.definition: embittered, angry, πικρὰ ὄρνις S. Ant. 423.

relentless, οὐδὲν πικρότερον τῆς ἀνάγκης Antipho 2.2.4 ; spiteful, mean, vindictive, βάσκανον καὶ πικρὸν καὶ κακόηθες οὐδέν ἐστι πολίτευμα ἐμόν D. 18.108; π. καὶ συκοφάντης Id. 25.45, cf. Arist. Rh. 1368b21, EN 1126a19 : in Com. of old men, σκυθρός, π., φειδωλός Men. 10, cf. 825, 843, Georg.Fr. 3. Adv. -ρῶς pedantically, D.H. Lys. 6; with rigid accuracy, Apollon.Cit. 3, Plu. QConv. 2.659f.

data.quote: βάσκανον καὶ πικρὸν καὶ κακόηθες οὐδέν ἐστι πολίτευμα ἐμόν

children.label: IV
children.definition: Adv. -ρῶς harshly, bitterly, vindictively, A. Pr. 197, S. OC 990 ; π. ἐξετάσαι D. 2.27, 18.265 ; π. ἔχειν τισί, πρός τινας, Id. 10.54, Ep. 3.10 ; π. φέρειν τι E. Ion 610, cf. Andr. 190; ἔκλαυσε π. Ev.Matt. 26.75 : Comp. -ότερον Men. Mon. 659, etc.: Sup. -ότατα Plb. 1.72.3. [ ῑ in Hom. and Ep.; ῐ freq. in Trag., as A. Pers. 473, Ag. 970, S. Aj. 500, E. Hec. 772, and in Theoc. 8.74 : ι therefore is not long by nature as in μικρός.]
pungency, of taste, bitterness, Hp. Acut. 23, VM 19, Pl. Tht. 159e, Ti. 83b : in pl., ib. 82e.

children.label: II
children.definition: bitterness, harshness, cruelty, τὴν [Ἀστυάγεος] π. Hdt. 1.130 ; γλώσσῃ π. ἔνεστί τις E. El. 1014 : pl., αἱ τῶν συκοφαντῶν π. Isoc. 15.300.
full of bitter bile, bilious, opp. μελάγχολος ; οἱ π. τὰ ἄνω Hp. Acut. 34, cf. 61, Aret. SA 1.5 ; π. χυμός Gal. 6.247 : metaph., splenetic, AP 7.69 ( Jul.).
make bitter :— Pass., become so, Alex.Aphr. Pr. 2.70.
= Lat. pila, mortar, POxy. 1890.12 (vi A. D.).
eye-salve, Aët. 7.103, Paul.Aeg. 7.16, Alex.Trall. 2.
plaster, Orib. Fr. 90.
cap, Leonid. ap. Aët. 6.1.
= Lat. pileus, cj. in Plb. 30.18.3 ; cf. πιλίον.
EM 672.12), compress wool, make it into felt, πιληθεὶς πέτασος a felt hat, AP 6.282 ( Theod.).

children.label: II
children.definition: compress, close up, πιλοῦντες ἑαυτούς Ar. Lys. 577 ; πιλήσαντες τοὺς λόχους D.H. 9.58; make firm or solid, π. καὶ πυκνοῦν τὴν σάρκα, τὸ σῶμα, Gal. 11.758, 394; τρίψει . . π. τὸ δέρμα Id. 6.417 :— Pass., to be close pressed, διὰ τὸ πολὺ εἰς ὀλίγον πιληθῆναι τόπον Arist. Mete. 366b13 ; χθὼν . . οὔπω πιληθεῖσα made solid, A.R. 4.678; ὕδατι πιληθεῖσα μᾶζα kneaded, APl. 16.333 ( Antiphil.); to be condensed, [ σελήνην] νέφος εἶναι πεπιλημένον Xenoph. ap. Placit. 2.25.4 ; of air, Hero Spir. 1 Praef.; of a man, παγκρατιαστὴς ὑπὸ τῆς πυκνότητος σαρκῶν πεπιλημένος Ph. 2.449, cf. Porph. Chr. 35 ; ἰσχνός, τὴν σάρκα πεπιλ. J. BJ 6.1.6 ; τοῖς χείλεσι πιλουμένοις compressed, Sch.D.T. p.43 H.

data.quote: διὰ τὸ πολὺ εἰς ὀλίγον πιληθῆναι τόπον
παγκρατιαστὴς ὑπὸ τῆς πυκνότητος σαρκῶν πεπιλημένος

children.definition: π. πουλύπουν pound a polypus so as to make it tender, πουλύπου πιλουμένου Ar. Fr. 191 ; π. πλεκτάνας Eub. 150.7, cf. Arist. HA 622a16 ( Pass.), Zen. 3.24.
Pass., to be oppressed, overwhelmed, κακοῖς Hegesias ap. D.H. Comp. 18 ; τῷ θανάτῳ πεπιλημένος Agath. 5.3.
compressed wool or hair, felt, Dsc. 1.58, Gal. 12.504 ; π. τῆς πολυτελεστάτης πορφύρας Duris 14 J., cf. Posidon. 9 ( a) J.
anything made thereof, hat (cf. πῖλος), Call. Fr. 124, 125.

children.label: II
children.definition: compression, νιφετοῦ βρῖθος ἐκ π. λαβόντος Arist. Mu. 394b2, cf. Anaximand. ap. Placit. 2.13.7; π. φλογός, of the angelʼs sword, Ph. 1.143 ; π. αἰθέριον, αἰθέρος, of the sun and moon, ib. 284, 624.

definition: πιλήσει, for φιλήσεις, barbarism in Ar. Th. 1190.

children.definition: compression of wool, felt, Pl. Lg. 849c.

children.label: II
children.definition: compression, solidification, esp. of contraction by cold, Id. Ti. 76c, cf. Xenoph. ap. Placit. 3.4.4, Pl. Ti. 58b, Thphr. CP 5.8.3 (v.l. πιλώσει) ; compression of air, Ph. Bel. 77.22 ; opp. ἐξάπλωσις, Ph. 1.385 : pl., πιλήσεις ἀέρος Epicur. Ep. 2p.44U., cf. Gal. Nat.Fac. 1.3.

children.label: III
children.definition: overloading of animals, Anon. ap. Suid. (pl.).
of or for felt-making : ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) felterʼs art, Pl. Plt. 280c.

children.label: II
children.definition: contractive, Arist. Pr. 909b18 ; π. δύναμις Gal. 11.711; τὸ π. cj. for τὸ πλατικόν in Hp. Cord. 8.
made of felt, κτήματα Pl. Ti. 74b, Gal. UP 6.4; στολαί Agatharch. 20; φοινικίδες D.S. 17.115; θώρακες Anon. ap. Suid. s.v. πίλοις.

children.label: II
children.definition: compressible, Arist. Mete. 385a17, 387a15.

definition: πιλίδιον, τό, Dim. of πῖλος, Ar. Ach. 439, Antiph. 33.4, Pl. R. 406d, D. 19.255.

children.definition: made of felt, ὑποδήματα IG 5(1).1390.23 ( Andania, i B. C.), cf. Poll. 7.171.
Dim. of πῖλος II, Arist. Fr. 235, PCair.Zen. 659.23 (iii B. C.), PTeb. 230 (ii B. C.), Plb. 35.6.4, Plu. Flam. 13.
bandage, Sor. Fasc. 2.
wanting the letter π, Theoc. Syrinx 4 (fort. πειλιπής, cf. πεῖ).

definition: πιλίσκος, ὁ, Dim. of πῖλος, Dsc. 3.4.

children.definition: = Lat. pilleatus, freedman, Arr. Epict. 4.7.37 (pl.).

bring near, once in Hes., Βορέας . . δρῦς . . πιλνᾷ χθονί brings them to earth, Op. 510 ; also intr., δόμοισι πιλνᾷς thou drawest nigh to the house, h.Cer. 115 (nisi leg. πίλνασαι) :—elsewh. Pass. πίλνᾰμαι (with no act. form πίλνημι), draw near to, approach, c. dat., ἅρματα χθονὶ πίλνατο the chariots went close to the ground, Il. 23.368 ; ἐπʼ οὔδει πίλναται 19.93, cf. A.R. 4.952, Simm. 7 : abs. with two subjects, Γαῖα καὶ Οὐρανὸς πίλνατο earth and sky threatened to encounter (in the storm), Hes. Th. 703 :— πίτναντο must be read for πίλναντο with Aristarch. and some codd. in Il. 22.402 ; conversely πίλναντο for πίτναντο in Euph. 63.2.
like a cap, Cleanth.Stoic. 1.113 ( πηλ- codd.), Heliod. ap. Orib. 48.50.1 ( πηλ-). Adv. -δῶς Sor. 1.14 (rest. from Orib.).
felting, Poll. 7.171.
good for felting, πηλοποιικὸν (sic) ὕδωρ Gal. 13.938 ( πῑλο-ποιητικός ib. 361); ἡ -κή the felterʼs art, Poll. 7.171.
felt-maker, hatter, Poll. 1.149, 7.171.

wool or hair wrought into felt, used as a lining for helmets, Il. 10.265 ; for shoes, Hes. Op. 542, cf. Pl. Smp. 220b, Luc. Rh.Pr. 15; but τὴν τῶν οἰκείων πίλων γένεσιν, playfully, of the human hair, Pl. Lg. 942e.

children.label: II
children.definition: anything made of felt, esp. close-fitting cap, Hes. Op. 546, Arist. GA 785a27, AP 6.90 ( Phil.), etc.; πίλους τιάρας φορέοντες wearing turbans for caps, Hdt. 3.12; ἀντὶ τῶν π. μιτρηφόροι ἦσαν Id. 7.62, cf. 61, 92 ; πῖλοι τοῖς δημοσίοις IG 2(2).1672.70 ; π. λευκός ib. 5(1).1390.13 ( Andania, i B. C.); of various fashions, π. Ἀρκαδικός Polyaen. 4.14; Λακωνικός Poll. 1.149 ; Μακεδονικός, = καυσία, Id. 10.162 ; π. χαλκοῦς a brazen cap, i. e. helmet, Ar. Lys. 562 ; of the apex worn by Roman flamines, D.H. 2.64 (pl.).
felt shoe, λευκοὺς ὑπὸ ποσσὶν ἔχων π. Cratin. 100.
felt cloth, used for carpets, mats, tents, etc., Hdt. 4.23, 73, 75, Hp. Aër. 18 (pl.), cf. X. Cyr. 5.5.7, Aen.Tact. 33.3 (pl.), etc.; for horse-cloths, Plu. Art. 11.
felt cuirass, jerkin, Th. 4.34.

children.label: III
children.definition: amadou, Polyporus igniarius, Thphr. HP 3.7.4.

children.label: b
children.definition: embryo of Nelumbium, ib. 4.8.7.
ball, σφαιρίζουσα πίλῳ Suid. Hist.( FHG ii p.464) Fr. 2.

children.label: IV
children.definition: = Lat. pilus, as in primus pilus, Suid. (Cf. Lat. pilleus.)
wear a πῖλος or apex, like the Roman flamines, App. BC 1.65.
accustomed to wear a πῖλος, Luc. Scyth. 1.
wearing a cap, Ἀρμένιοι AP 9.430 ( Crin.); of the Dacian nobles, D.C. 68.9.

definition: πιλόω, = πιλέω, of the effect of cold,

children.definition: contract, opp. μανόω, ὁ χειμὼν πιλώσας τὰς ῥίζας Thphr. CP 3.23.5 :— Pass., ib. 1.12.3 ; νέφη ἐκ τῶν ἀτμῶν πιλοῦσθαι Democr. ap. Placit. 4.1.4.

data.quote: μανόω, ὁ χειμὼν πιλώσας τὰς ῥίζας

children.definition: like felt : close-pressed, Ptol. Judic. p.25 B. ( Comp.).
of felt, σκηναὶ π., of the Scythians, Str. 7.3.17 ; τιάρας περικείμενοι πιλωτάς Id. 15.3.15.

children.label: II
children.definition: compressed, = Lat. densus, Serv.Dan.ad Verg. A. 12.121.

soft fat, lard, Hdt. 2.40, 47, Hp. Aër. 19, S. Ant. 1011, Democr. ap. Ael. NA 12.18, Alex. 83 : distd. from στέαρ as being χυτὸν καὶ ἄπηκτον, Arist. HA 520a8, cf. PA 651a20; ἡ ἐπιπολάζουσα [γάλακτι] π., of cream, Philostr. Im. 1.31.
fat, Aq. Jd. 3.17, Luc. Tim. 15, Babr. 100.1, etc.: Comp. -έστερος Luc. Symp. 43.
sepulchre of fat, Cerc. 7.5.
like fat, fatty, Arist. PA 652a7, al.; τὸ π. Hp. Art. 41.
spicer, apothecary, Olymp. in Grg. p.362 J., al., cj. for ποιμενταρίων (v.l. ποιμενικῶν) in Aët. 15.29. (Late Lat. pi(g)mentarius.)

definition: πιμπλάνομαι, Ep. pass. form, = πίμπλαμαι, Il. 9.679.

children.definition: πίμπλα Xenarch. 3 codd.; pres. part. πιμπλῶν, -ῶσαι, LXX Si. 24.25, Hp. Epid. 6.8.7, ἐμ-πιπλῶντα v.l. in Id. Morb. 2.12: impf. ἐπίμπλων Lyr.Adesp. 90 :— Pass. πιμπλῶνται Hp. Morb. 1.32.
Call. Del. 7, Str. 7 Fr. 18, 9.2.25:— Adj. Πιμπληϊάς, κούρη v.l. in Orph. Fr. 342; Πιμπληΐδες Μοῦσαι AP 5.205 ( Leon.); σκοπιὴ Πιμπληΐς, Π. ἄκρη, A.R. 1.25, Epic. in EM 588.4.

definition: πίμπλημι, in pres. and impf. formed like ἵστημι; Aeol. 3 pl. πίμπλεισι Alc. Supp. 25.3; Ep. 3 sg. subj. πιμπλῇσι Hes. Op. 301; imper. πίμπλη cj. in Xenarch. 3, ἐμ-πίμπλη Ar. Av. 1310; part. πιμπλάς Pl. R. 586b; but nom.pl.fem. πιμπλεῖσαι Hes. Th. 880: impf. 3 pl. ἐπίμπλασαν X. An. 1.5.10: other tenses from πλήθω (which in pres. and impf. is intr.): fut. πλήσω E. Hipp. 692, ( ἀνα-) Od. 5.302: aor. ἔπλησα E. Med. 905, etc.; Ep. πλῆσα Il. 13.60, al.: pf. πέπληκα ( ἐμ-) Pl. Ap. 23e, Ly. 204d:— Med., fut. πλήσομαι ( ἐμ-) Arat. 1121, App. Syr. 7: aor. ἐπλησάμην Il. 9.224, etc.:— Pass., fut. πλησθήσομαι Ev.Luc. 1.15, Charito 5.5, Him. Or. 23.14, ( ἐμ-) E. Hipp. 664, Isoc. 6.69; also πεπλήσομαι Porph. Abst. 1.16: aor. ἐπλήσθην Il. 20.156, etc.; Ep. 3 pl. πλῆσθεν 17.211, Od. 4.705: pf. πέπλησμαι Babr. 60, ( ἐμ-) Pl. R. 518b, 3 pl. πεπλήαται Semon. 31 A, πέπληνται Hp. Flat. 8; also shortd. form πλῆνται Parm. 1.13: aor. 2 ἐπλήμην, Ep. 3 sg. and pl. πλῆτο, πλῆντο, Il. 17.499, Od. 8.57, Parm. 12.1; ἐν-έπλητο Ar. V. 911, 1304; imper. ἔμ-πλησο ib. 603; opt. ἐμ-πλῄμην, -ῇτο, Id. Ach. 236, Lys. 235; part. ἐμ-πλήμενος Id. V. 424, 984, etc.—In the compd. ἐμπίμπλημι (q.v.; more freq. in Prose) the second μ is sts. dropped, as ἐμπίπλημι; but returns with the augm., as in ἐνεπίμπλασαν; cf. πίμπρημι :—

children.definition: fill, c. gen.rei, fill full of . . , τράπεζαν ἀμβροσίης Od. 5.93; πήρην σίτου καὶ κρειῶν 17.411; π. τινὰ μένεος, θάρσευς φρένας, Il. 13.60, 17.573; καλάμης τὸ πλοῖον Hdt. 1.194; π. κρητῆρα κακῶν A. Ag. 1398; πίμπλημʼ ὄμμα δακρύων S. El. 906; δακρύων ἔπλησεν ἐμέ filled me full of tears, E. Or. 368: c. dat. rei, fill with . . , ἰαχῇ τε φόβῳ τε πάσας πλῆσαν ὁδούς Il. 16.374; δακρύοις Ἑλλάδʼ ἅπασαν ἔπλησεν E. Or. 1363 (lyr.); simply, fill, ἰχθύες . . πιμπλᾶσι μυχούς Il. 21.23, cf. 14.35, Hes. Op. 411, Pl. Grg. 494a; π. μέλος A. Fr. 57.4: abs., πίμπλη σὺ μὲν ἐμοί (sc. τὴν κύλικα) Xenarch. 3.

data.quote: ἰαχῇ τε φόβῳ τε πάσας πλῆσαν ὁδούς

children.definition: fill full, satisfy, glut, E. Cyc. 146, etc.
fill, discharge an office, A. Ch. 361 (dub.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Med., fill for oneself, or what is oneʼs own, πλησάμενος οἴνοιο δέπας having filled himself a cup of wine, Il. 9.224, cf. Od. 14.112, etc.; π. νῆας load ships, ib. 87; π. . . θυμὸν ἐδητύος ἠδὲ ποτῆτος fill up, satiate oneʼs desire with . . , 17.603; ματρόθεν δυσώνυμα λέκτρʼ ἐπλήσω S. OC 528 (lyr.); πεδία πίμπλασθʼ ἁρμάτων fill the plain full of your chariots, v.l. in E. Ph. 522.

children.label: III
children.definition: Pass., to be filled, be full of, τῶν . . ἐπλήσθη πεδίον Il. 20.156; πλῆτο ῥόος . . ἵππων τε καὶ ἀνδρῶν 21.16; ὄσσε δακρυόφι πλῆσθεν Od. 4.705, etc.; μένεος . . φρένες . . πίμπλαντο Il. 1.104; πλῆσθεν . . μέλεʼ ἐντὸς ἀλκῆς 17.211; ἀλκῆς πλῆτο φρένας . . ib. 499; ἀϋτῆς . . ἐπλήσθη στέγος E. Heracl. 646: rarely c. dat., λέκτρα δʼ ἀνδρῶν πόθῳ πίμπλαται δακρύμασι A. Pers. 134 (lyr.); δάκρυσι τὸ στράτευμα πλησθέν Th. 7.75.

data.quote: πλῆτο ῥόος . . ἵππων τε καὶ ἀνδρῶν
λέκτρα δʼ ἀνδρῶν πόθῳ πίμπλαται δακρύμασι

children.definition: to be filled, satisfied, have enough of a thing, αἱμάτων γένυσιν πλησθῆναι S. Ant. 121; π. τῆς νόσου ξυνουσίᾳ to be wearied of it by being with it, Id. Ph. 520; ἡδονῶν Pl. R. 442a, etc.
become pregnant, Arist. HA 576b29, 578b32. (Cf. Skt. piparti ‘fill’, pūrṇá-, Lat. plenus, Goth. fulls, etc. ‘full’.)

definition: πίμπρημι, pres. and impf. non-thematic; imper. πίμπρη E. Ion 527, 974; part. nom. pl. πιμπράντες Th. 6.94; inf. πιμπράναι A. Pers. 810, E. Tr. 81, ( ἐμ-) Plb. 11.5.6, etc.: impf. ἐν-επίμπρην Th. 6.94; 3 pl. ἐνεπίμπρασαν X. HG 6.5.32 :—other tenses formed from πρήθω (q. v.): fut. πρήσω A. Th. 434, ( ἐμ-) Il. 9.242, etc.: aor. ἔπρησα 2.415, E. Andr. 390, etc.; 3 sg. shortd. ἔπρεσε Hes. Th. 856: pf. πέπρηκα ( ὑπο-, ἐμ-, κατα-) Hp. Ep. 17, Alciphr. 1.32, D.C. 59.16:— Med., Nic. Al. 345: aor. ἐπρησάμην ( ἐν-) Q.S. 5.485:— Pass., fut. πρησθήσομαι LXX Nu. 5.27; πεπρήσομαι (v.l. πρήσομαι ( ἐμ-)) Hdt. 6.9: aor. ἐπρήσθην Hp. Nat.Mul. 10, Amphis 30.10 (dub.), ( ἐν-) Hdt. 8.55, Pl. Grg. 469e: pf. ( ἐμ-) πέπρησμαι Hdt. 8.144, Paus. 2.5.5; but πέπρημαι is the Att. form acc. to Phot. s.v. σέσωται, and ἐμ-πέπρημαι is found in Ar. V. 36 cod. Rav.; imper. πέπρησο Pherecr. 80.—Collat. pres. ἐμ-πιπράω (v. ἐμπίμπρημι).—In the compd. ἐμπίμπρημι (q. v.; more freq. in Prose) the second μ is sts. dropped, as ἐμπίπρημι; but returns with the augm., as ἐνεπίμπρασαν; cf. πίμπλημι :—

children.definition: burn, burn up, γῆν . . πυρὶ πρῆσαι κατάκρας S. Ant. 201, cf. E. Tr. 81; πρῆσαι δὲ πυρὸς . . θύρετρα Il. 2.415, cf. 9.242 (v.l.); without πυρί or πυρός, Hes. Th. 856; πρήσω πόλιν A. Th. 434, cf. Pers. 810; δῶμα E. Andr. 390, etc.:— Pass., πίμπραμαι to be burnt, Ar. Lys. 341; πέπρησο burn with fever, Pherecr. 80, cf. SIG 1180.10 ( Cnidus); of wounds, to be inflamed, Nic. Th. 306 (but intr. in Act. πίμπρησι δὲ χείλη Id. Al. 438): metaph., ἐπί τινι πίμπρασθαι Luc. Jud.Voc. 8; ἐπὶ Ῥωμαίοις App. Ital. 3.

children.label: II
children.definition: blow up, distend, in Pass., Hp. Nat.Mul. 10, Flat. 8, Nic. Al. 477, Act.Ap. 28.6 (v.l.); ἐπέπρητο ὅλα IG 42(1).122.123 (Epid.) :— Act., Arist. HA 522b28, Dsc. 4.32. (Cf. Russ. prět' ‘sweat’, ‘stew’.)
like planks, ῥήματα π. ἀποσπῶν Ar. Ra. 824, cf. Sch.adloc.
of the size or thickness of a πίναξ, Hippiatr. 104.
seller of πινακίδες, Hdn.Gr. 2.657 ( πινακᾶς Lentz).
Hp. Epid. 6.8.7, Arist. Mir. 834b12, Sm. Ez. 9.2, Gal. 7.855; writing-tablet, Plu. Eum. 1.
of or by means of tables, τῶν ἀστέρων θεωρία Vett.Val. 173.26, cf. Ptol. Tetr. 120, Paul.Al. L. 1. Adv. - κῶς in tabular form, Ptol. Tetr. 53.

Dim. of πίναξ, small tablet on which the δικασταί wrote their verdict, π. τιμητικόν Ar. V. 167, cf. Arist. Pol. 1268a2; εὶς π. γράφειν Pl. Lg. 753c; also used in drawing lots for offices, D. 39.12; π. πύξινον, given to dicasts as badge of office, Arist. Ath. 63.4.

notice-board on which laws, decrees, etc. were written, Ar. Av. 450, Plu. Per. 30, etc.; ἐν πινακίῳ λελευκωμένῳ IG 2(2).1237.62, cf. 12.66.31; also for notices of charges against officials, Arist. Ath. 48.4, cf. D. 8.28, PHal. 1.225 (iii B. C.); ἀναγράψαντες ἐμ π. τὸ μέτρον τοῦ καρποῦ IG 1(2).76.27.

data.quote: ἀναγράψαντες ἐμ π. τὸ μέτρον τοῦ καρποῦ

children.definition: tablets, memorandum book, τά τε π. καὶ τὰ γραμματεῖα ib. 91.11; π. ὀνειροκριτικόν Plu. Arist. 27.
votive tablet, IG 2(2).1388.57.

children.label: II
children.definition: tablet for painting upon, τὰ τῶν ζωγράφων π. Thphr. HP 3.9.7, cf. Inscr.Délos 290.100 (p.191, iii B.C.), Luc. Im. 17.

children.label: b
children.definition: small or bad picture, Isoc. 15.2.
small plate or dish, Arr. Epict. 1.19.4, 2.22.31; π. ἀργυροῦν BGU 387ii10, etc.
astronomical table, π. ἀστρολογικόν ib. 1674.8 (ii A. D.).

= foreg. [πινάκιον] I.3 [tablets, memorandum book], Philyll. 11, Macho ap. Ath. 13.582c; in the Kingdom of Bosporus, ἐπὶ τῆς π., as title, prob. in IPE 2.29.29 ( Panticapaeum, iii A. D.), cf. BMus.Inscr. 183 ( πινακεῖδος): pl., π. Ἑλληνικαί codicils in Greek, PGnom. 36 (ii A. D.).
tablets, Plu. TG 6, Id. Aud. 2.47e, Arr. Epict. 1.10.5.

children.label: II
children.definition: dance, Poll. 4.103, Ath. 14.629f.

definition: πινακίσκιον, τό, Dim. of sq., Antiph. 55.8.

children.definition: Dim. of πίναξ 2, Ar. Pl. 813, Fr. 532, Pherecr. 108.14, Pl.Com. 119, Lync. 1.6.
inscribe on a πίναξ, in Pass., Eust. 633.25 ( Pass.), etc.
drawing of maps, Str. 2.1.11.
in the manner of a map, Eust. 1167.39.
map-maker, Eust. ad D.P. 4.

children.label: II
children.definition: maker of lists or catalogues, St.Byz. s.v. Ἄβδηρα.
like a tablet, Diogenian. 5.72.
picture-gallery, Str. 14.1.14.
tablet-maker, PTeb. 278.16 (i A.D.).
one who sells small birds plucked and ranged upon a board, Ar. Av. 14, cf. Sch.
timber-work, Plu. QConv. 2.658e.
board, plank, πίνακάς τε νεῶν Od. 12.67; εὐγόμφοισιν . . πινάκεσσιν Opp. H. 1.194, cf. πινακηδόν; πίνακος κουρά sawdust, Hsch.: hence of things made of flat wood, metal, etc.,

drawing- or writing-tablet, = δέλτος, γράψας ἐν π. πτυκτῷ Il. 6.169; πίναξιν . . ἐγγεγραμμένα A. Supp. 946; πινάκων ξεστῶν δέλτοι Ar. Th. 778; ἐν χρυσῷ π. γράψαντες Pl. Criti. 120c, cf. R. 501a; of a votive tablet hung on the image of a god, A. Supp. 463, cf. Arist. Pol. 1341a36, IG 42(1).121.24 ( Epid., iv B.C., pl.), Herod. 4.19, Str. 8.6.15 (pl.), etc.; Πίνακες tables or catalogues of authors, name of a work by Callimachus, D.L. 8.86, cf. Ath. 6.244a, 13.585b, Suid. s.v. Καλλίμαχος; lists of philosophers, Plu. Sull. 26; αἵ τʼ ἀναγραφαὶ τῶν π. αἵ τε βυβλιοθῆκαι Phld. Sto. 339.13.

data.quote: αἵ τʼ ἀναγραφαὶ τῶν π. αἵ τε βυβλιοθῆκαι

children.definition: trencher, platter, κρειῶν πίνακας παρέθηκεν Od. 1.141, cf. 16.49; ἐπʼ ἀργυροῦ π. Philippid. 9.4; π. χαλκοῦς Ath. 4.128d; salver, πίνακα . . μέγαν, ἔχοντα μικροὺς πέντε πινακίσκους Lync. 1.5, cf. 17, 19; πίνακες ὑέλινοι Aët. 7.106.

data.quote: πίνακα . . μέγαν, ἔχοντα μικροὺς πέντε πινακίσκους

children.definition: board for painting on, picture, Simon. 178, Anaxandr. 33.2; π. οἱ γραφόμενοι Thphr. HP 5.7.4, cf. IG 11(2).161 A 75 ( Delos, iii B. C.).
plate with anything drawn or engraved on it, χάλκεος π., of a map, Hdt. 5.49, cf. Plu. Thes. 1; π. γεωγραφικός, first made by Anaximander, Str. 1.1.11.
board or tablet on which astronomical tables were drawn, ἡ περὶ πίνακα μέθοδος the art of casting nativities, Plu. Rom. 12; ἀγυρτικοὶ π. Id. Comp.Arist.Cat. 3.5, cf. πινάκιον II 3.

children.label: b
children.definition: ἐκ πίνακος καὶ πυλαίας, of a trivial fiction, Id. E apud Delph. 2.386b.
public notice-board or register, π. ἐκκλησιαστικός D. 44.35, etc.; but δαμόσιος π. public archive, SIG 671 A 15 ( Delph., ii B. C.).
strop, to sharpen knives on, Thphr. HP 5.5.1.
toy-theatre for marionettes, Hero Aut. 23.1, al. (Cf. OSlav. pǐnǐ ‘tree-stump’.)
vitriol, Dsc. [5.98].

children.label: II
children.definition: piece of mother-of-pearl (cf. πίνη), PHolm. 3.12, PSI 3.183.5 (V A.D.).
to be dirty, Suid. s.v. πεπελτωμένα.
dirty, squalid, Cratin. 372, E. El. 184 (lyr.); πιναρὸν . . ἀλουτίᾳ κάρα Eup. 251; of unwashed wool, Aret. CA 1.1; cf. πινηρός.
filthiness, Eust. 1561.25.
JHS 25.174 ( Isaura), Papers of Amer. Sch.at Athens 3 No.207 ( Pisidia), unless a pr. n.
to be dirty, Ar. Lys. 279.
of Pindar, ἔπος Ar. Av. 939 (lyr.):—also Πινδᾰρικός, ή, όν, Plu. Exil. 2.602f; σχῆμα Π. Eust. 1110.52. Adv. -κῶς Id. 21.14.
from Mount Pindus, Pi. P. 1.66.

pinna, a long-shaped bivalve, with a silky beard or byssus, of which several species inhabit the Mediterranean, freq. mentioned as a delicacy in Com. Poets, e. g. Cratin. 8, Philyll. 13, cf. Arist. HA 528a24, 547b15, Isid.Char. 20, Opp. H. 2.187, Artem. 2.14.

children.label: II
children.definition: pearl, acc. pl. πίνας UPZ 121.9 (ii B. C.); πείνας POxy. 1273.10 (iii A. D.), cf. ἀληθινόπινος, πινώτιον, πινάριον.—Written with one ν, UPZ l.c., POxy. l.c., and sts. in codd., cf. Cic. Fin. 3.63, ND 2.123, Plin. HN 9.115, 142; πῖνα Hdn.Gr. 2.570, Hsch., Choerob. in An.Ox. 2.250; the spelling πινν- in this word and its derivatives is freq. in codd., but is not found in Inscrr. or Papyri.
Ion. for πιναρός, ἔρια πινηρά Hp. ap. Erot.
of the πινικόν, π. κόγχος, = πινικόν, Peripl.M.Rubr. 35: πῑνικόν, τό, pearl produced by the πίνη, ib. 36, 59.
mother-of-pearl, LXX Es. 1.6 (v.l. πίννινος).
liquor made from barley, beer, Arist. Fr. 106, cj. in Atti della reale Accad. di Archeologia di Napoli 11.41 ( Gortyn, iv B. C.).

to be dirty, χιτὼν πεπινωμένος Philet. 17; of Alexanderʼs complexion as painted by Apelles, Plu. Alex. 4: metaph. (cf. πίνος 2), literae πεπινωμέναι or πεπινωμένως scriptae, in archaic style, Cic. Att. 14.7.2, 15.16; ἡ αὐστηρὰ καὶ πεπ. σύνθεσις D.H. Dem. 45.
dirt, filth, in clothes or hair, S. OC 1259, E. El. 305; of the natural grease in wool, Paul.Aeg. 7.17.88: metaph., σὺν πίνῳ χερῶν, i.e. by foul means, A. Ag. 776 (lyr.).
patina on bronze statues, Plu. Pyth. 2.395b: hence, metaph. of style, ὁ τῆς ἀρχαιότητος π. D.H. Dem. 5, cf. 39, Comp. 11, al.
wash on metals, Olymp.Alch. p.75 B. [ πίνος Hdn.Gr. 2.945, and ῐ in Poets, S. l.c., A.R. 2.200, etc.: πῖνος is incorrect in Phryn. PS p.37 B. cod., EM 672.39.]
pinna-guard, a small crab that lives in the pinnaʼs shell, said to give warning of approaching danger, Arist. HA 547b28, Chrysipp.Stoic. 2.207, Plu. Sollert. 2.980b; cf. πινυφύλαξ.
Ar. V. 1510; ὁ π. τοῦδε μάντεως χορός (prob. for χοροῦ), posted to give warning, S. Fr. 113.
nourishing the pinna, Tz.ad Lyc. 418.
Arist. HA 547b16, Isid.Char. 20, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.98, Artem. 2.14.
cubical block of masonry, Sch. Pi. O. 2.146.
= sq., Hsch. s.v. πινυμένην: πίνῠσις [ πῐ], εως, ἡ, prudence, Id.

definition: πινύσκω and πῐνύσσω, Ep. aor. ἐπίνυσσα: aor. Pass. ἐπινύσθην :—

children.definition: make prudent, admonish, correct, ἤδη γάρ με καὶ ἄλλο τεὴ ἐπίνυσσεν ἐφετμή Il. 14.249; ἀφραδέοντα πινυσσέμεν Naumach. ap. Stob. 4.23.7; ἐκεῖνον . . πινύσκετʼ εὐλόγοισι νουθετήμασι A. Pers. 830; κερδαλέῳ μύθῳ σε πινύσκει Call. Dian. 152; ὁπόταν πινύσκῃ ζεὺς ἄματα makes the days calm, Simon. 12; simply, teach, ταλασήϊα ἔργα Orph. Fr. 178:— Pass., ὑπὸ τᾶς ματρὸς πινυσθείς Pythag ap. Iamb. VP 28.146. (Cf. πέπνυμαι.)

data.quote: ἤδη γάρ με καὶ ἄλλο τεὴ ἐπίνυσσεν ἐφετμή

children.definition: understanding, wisdom, Il. 7.289, Od. 20.71, Hp. Ep. 18.

definition: πινυτής, ῆτος, Dor. ᾶτος, ἡ, = foreg., AP 7.490 ( Anyt.).

children.definition: prudent, discreet, Od. 1.229, 4.211, 11.445, etc.; πινυτὸς θυμόν Pi. I. 8(7).28; πάντα ἄρτια καὶ π. Sol. 4.40, cf. Luc. Bacch. 8: Comp. - ώτερος Q.S. 5.166. Adv. -τῶς, λέγειν Epicr. 11.6 (anap.).—Poet. word, cf. Plu. An seni 2.797e.

of wise or understanding mind, of Odysseus, Q.S. 14.630, AP 3.8 ( Inscr. Cyzic.); εὐμαθίη ib. 7.22 ( Simm.); σιγή APl. 16.325 ( Jul.); ingenious, εὐχωλή (of an acrostic) Puchstein Epigr.Gr. p.10; νοῦς Jul. Caes. 319a; restd. in Epic.Alex.Adesp. 7.19.

definition: πίνω [ῑ], Ep. inf. πινέμεναι and - έμεν, Il. 4.346, Od. 7.220 : Ion. impf. πίνεσκον Il. 16.226: fut. πίομαι 13.493, Thgn. 962, A. Ch. 578, S. OC 622, Ar. Eq. 1289, 1401, Fr. 311; later πῐοῦμαι Arist. Rh. 1370b18, Ael. VH 12.49, etc.; also as f.l. in earlier authors, πιεῖσθαι Hp. Int. 12, πιεῖσθε X. Smp. 4.7, but rejected by Phryn. 23, Ath. 10.446d; 2 sg. πίεσαι LXX De. 28.39, Ev.Luc. 17.8: aor. ἔπῐον, Ep. πίον Il. 22.2, etc.; 2 sg. subj. πίῃσθα 6.260; imper. πίε Od. 9.347, Men. 151, Carm.Pop. 33, ( ἐκ-) E. Cyc. 563, Orph. Fr. 32 b iii; also πῖθι Cratin. 141, Ion Trag. 27, Ar. V. 1489, Amips. 18, Antiph. 163.1, etc., ( ἔκ-) E. Cyc. 570; πίει, πίεις, Kretschmer Griech. Vaseninschr. p.195; inf. πιεῖν Od. 8.70, Hdt. 4.172, etc.; later contr. πεῖν AP 11.140 ( Lucill.), Mim.Oxy. 413.66, PMag.Lond. 121.738, PFlor. 101.8 (i A. D.), etc.; Ep. πῐέμεν Od. 15.378, πιέειν Il. 4.263, πιέναι f.l. for ὑπιέναι in Hp. Epid. 5.18; part. πῐών, πῐοῦσα, Il. 24.102, etc., πῐέουσα Hp. Epid. 7.11:— Med., subj. πινώμεθα Hermipp. 25; imper. πίνεο Nic. Th. 912: πίομαι [ῑ] as pres. Med., Ibyc. 17 (s.v.l.), Pi. O. 6.86, and so ἐκπίομαι [ῑ] Ar. Ach. 199, ἐμπίομαι [ῐ] Thgn. 1129 ( Pass. in AP 5.43 ( Rufin.)):— Pass., Od. 20.312, Hp. Aër. 9, etc.: Ep. impf. πίνετο Od. 9.45.—Other tenses are from πω- or πο-, pf. πέπωκα A. Th. 821, etc.:— Pass., fut. ποθήσομαι ( κατα-) Ar. V. 1502, ( ἐκ-) Plu. Apophth. Lac. 2.240e: aor. ἐπόθην ( ἐξ-) A. Ch. 66, ( κατ-) Pl. Criti. 111d: pf. inf. πεπόσθαι Thgn. 477: Aeol. pres. πώνω Alc. 20, 52, Supp. 20.3: aor. imper. πῶθι, τῶ, EM 698.52. [ ῑ always in πίνω. πίνομαι; ῐ always in aor. ἔπιον, hence πίε must be read for πῖνε in AP 11.19 ( Strat.), and ἔπῑνον for ἔπιον in Anacreont. 5.5: Hom. has ἐθέλουσι δὲ πῑέμεν ἄμφω Il. 16.825, cf. Od. 18.3; but καὶ φαγέμεν πῐέμεν τε 15.378; in imper. πῖθι, ῑ always.—In fut. πίομαι Hom. and Trag. use ῑ, Il. 13.493, A. Ch. 578, S. OC 622, cf. Thgn. 962, Ar. Eq. 1289, 1401, Fr. 311; but ῐ in lon Lyr. 2.10 (nisi leg. πιέτω), ( ἐκ-) Pl.Com. 9, Amips. 22; also in later Poetry, AP 11.8, 25.5 ( Apollonid.); for pres. Med. πίομαι, v. supr.]: —

children.definition: drink, freq. from Hom. downwds., c. acc., π. οἶνον, ὐρόν, αἷμα, etc., Od. 15.391, 17.225, S. OC 622, etc.; π. ὕδωρ Αἰσήποιο drink its water, i.e. live on its banks, Il. 2.825, cf. Pi. O. 6.86 ( Med.): c. gen. partit., drink of a thing, π. οἴνοιο Od. 22.11; εἰς οἶνον . . , ἔνθεν ἔπινον whereof . . , 4.220; αἵματος ὄφρα πίω 11.96, cf. 15.373; also πίνειν κρητῆρας οἴνοιο to drink bowls of wine, Il. 8.232; κύπελλα ὄνου 4.346; π. ἀπὸ κρήνης drink of a spring, Thgn. 959 (but κρήνης 962); π. ἀπʼ αὐτοῦ (sc. δέπαος) αἴθοπα οἶνον from it, Il. 16.226; δέπα ἔνθεν ἔπινον Od. 19.62; ἐκ κεράμων μέθυ πίνετο Il. 9.469; ἐκ τῆς χειρὸς διδοῖ πιεῖν Hdt. 4.172; ἐκ ταὐτοῦ . . ποτηρίου Ar. Eq. 1289; ἐξ ἀργύρου ἢ χρυσοῦ Pl. R. 417a; ἀπὸ τοῦ ποταμοῦ X. Cyr. 4.5.4; σκύφος ᾧ περ ἔπινεν with which . . , Od. 14.112; π. κερατίνοις ποτηρίοις v.l. in X. An. 6.1.4; τὰ φάρμακα π. παρὰ τοῦ ἰατροῦ draughts sent by him, Pl. Grg. 467c.

drink, ἐσθιέμεν καὶ πινέμεν Od. 2.305; ὁ πῖνε καὶ ἦσθε 5.94, 6.249, cf. Il. 24.476, etc.; μῆλα πιόμενʼ ἐκ βοτάνης going to drink after pasture, 13.493; πρὸς βίαν πώνην Alc. 20; πῖνε, πῖνʼ ἐπὶ συμφοραῖς Simon. 14; π. πρὸς ἡδονήν Pl. Smp. 176e; εἰς μέθην Id. Lg. 775b; διδόναι πιεῖν Cratin. 124; πιεῖν αἰτεῖν X. Cyr. 8.3.41; τινὶ πιεῖν ἐγχέας ib. 1.3.9; πιεῖν τις ἡμῖν ἐγχεάτω Philem. 9: in pf. πέπωκα, to be drunk, E. Cyc. 536; πίνοντά τε καὶ πεπωκότα drinking and having finished drinking, Pl. Phd. 117c.

children.label: II
children.definition: celebrate by a carouse, νίκην Philostr. Gym. 54.

children.label: III
children.definition: drink up, as the earth does rain, τὸ ὕδωρ, ὄμβρον, Hdt. 3.117, 4.198; πιοῦσα κόνις μέλαν αἷμα A. Eu. 979 (lyr.), cf. Th. 736 (lyr.), 821, S. OT 1401; of plants, X. Smp. 2.25; of a lamp, π. τοὔλαιον Luc. Cat. 27; λύχνος . . πολλὰ πιὼν μέλη AP 5.196 ( Mel., dub. l.). (I.-E. pōy- and pī-, cf. Skt. pāy-áyati ‘cause to drink’, pīti- ‘a drink’, Lat. pōtus, etc.)
greasy, of wool, Hp. Mul. 2.185 ( Sup.); dirty, foul, of hair, E. Or. 225, cf. Lyc. 975.
dirt, filth, Hsch.
pearl ear-ring, POxy. 1449.25 (iii A. D.).
shaped like the letter πῖ, μέρη [τοῦ διαπήγματος] Sor. 1.68; φλιά Orib. 49.4.30, 49.33.4. Adv. -δῶς Ruf. Anat. 45, cj. in Sor. 1.14.
fat, rich milk, Nic. Al. 77.
πίων, ἄρνες Epich. 136; μῆλα Orph. A. 506: hence πῑότερος, πῑότατος, v. πίων.
fattiness, τῆς σαρκός Hp. Aër. 21, cf. Arist. HA 520a23, PA 651b9, Thphr. HP 9.1.3.

children.label: II
children.definition: wealth, prosperity, Ph. 1.299, Eust. 1146.10.
with oily leaves, of the olive, etc., Alex.Aphr. in Top. 118.31.
lizard, Hsch.; also, = χαλκίς, Id.
pepper, POxy. 1299.10 (iv A. D.).

definition: πιπεράς, dub. in POxy. 921.26 (iii A. D.), PCornell 33 (iii A. D.);

children.definition: pepper-pot.
piperoterarium, Gloss.

definition: πιπίσκω, Hp. Mul. 1.63, Luc. Lex. 20: fut. πίσω [ῑ] Pi. I. 6(5).74, Eup. 115: aor. ἔπῑσα Hp. Mul. 1.59, al., prob. in Arist. EN 1111a14 (for παίσας), ( ἐν-) Pi. Fr. 111 ( πιπίσαι is f.l. in Hp. Fract. 36):— Med., aor. ἐπῑσάμην ( ἐν-) Nic. Th. 573, 877, etc.:— Pass., aor. ἐπίσθην ( ἐν-) ib. 624:—

children.definition: πίνω, give to drink, Hp. Acut. 2, Aret. CA 1.1, etc.: c. dupl. acc., πίσω σφε Δίρκας ὕδωρ I will make them drink the water of Dirce, Pi. I. l.c.; π. τινά τινος Luc. l.c.: c. dat. et acc., ταύτῃσι γάλα Hp. Mul. 1.63.
Arist. HA 609a30, 617a28.

children.label: II
children.definition: ὁ, a young piping bird, cj. for ἵππους in Ath. 9.368f.
pipe, cheep, or chirp like young birds, Ar. Av. 306.
Arist. HA 609a7.
seller of pistachio-nuts (cf. πιστάκη), MAMA 3.495 ( Corycus).

definition: πίπτω, Aeol. πίσσω, acc. to Gramm. in Hilgard Exc. ex libris Herodiani p.28 (cf. Hdn.Gr. 2.377 note); poet. subj. πίπτῃσι Pl.Com. 153.5: Ep. impf. πῖπτον Il. 8.67, etc. (for the quantity of ι cf. Hdn. Gr. 2.10); Ion. πίπτεσκον ( συμ-) Emp. 59.2: fut. πεσοῦμαι A. Ch. 971 (lyr.), etc.; Ion. 3 pl. πεσέονται Il. 11.824, 3 sg. πεσέεται Hdt. 7.163, 168: aor. ἔπεσον, inf. πεσεῖν, Il. 13.178, etc.; 2 sg. opt. πεσοίης Polem. Call. 10.14; Aeol. and Dor. ἔπετον Alc. 60, Pi. O. 7.69, P. 5.50, ( κάπετον) O. 8.38, ( ἐμ-) P. 8.81, cf. Isyll. 8, IG 14.642 ( Thurii); in later writers ἔπεσα, Orph. A. 521, LXX Le. 9.24, al., f.l. in E. Tr. 291 ( προσ-): pf. πέπτωκα A. Eu. 147, Ar. Ra. 970, etc.; Ep. part. πεπτεώς, εῶτος (the εω forming one syll. by synizesis), Il. 21.503, etc.; also πεπτηώς, ηυῖα, Od. 14.354, Simon. 183.7, Hp. Mul. 1.69, A.R. 4.1298, AP 7.427 ( Antip. Sid.), cf. πτήσσω; Trag. part. πεπτώς S. Aj. 828, Ant. 697. (Redupl. from πετ-, which appears in Aeol. and Dor. aor. ἔ-πετ-ον (v. supr.), and the poet. form πίτ-νω; cogn. with πέτομαι, q.v.)

children.label: A
children.definition: fall down, and (when intentional) cast oneself down, πρηνέα πεσεῖν, ὕπτιος πέσεν, Il. 6.307, 15.435, etc.; νιφάδες . . π. θαμειαί 12.278; ὀπίσω πέσεν Od. 12.410; etc.:—Constr., with Preps., in Hom. almost always ἐν . . , ἐν κονίῃσι π. fall in the dust, i.e. to rise no more, Il. 11.425, cf. 13.205; ἐν αἵματι καὶ κονίῃσι πεπτεῶτας Od. 22.384; π. ἐν ἀγκοίνῃσί τινος fall into his arms, Hes. Fr. 142.5; ἐν χθονὶ πεπτηώς Simon. l.c. (cf. πτήσσω) π. ἐν δεμνίοις E. Or. 35, cf. A. Pers. 125 (lyr.) (v. infr. B. I): rare in Prose, π. ἐν ποταμῷ X. Ages. 1.32: c. dat. only, πεδίῳ πέσε Il. 5.82; δεμνίοις π. E. Or. 88 (s. v.l.); π. ἐπὶ χθονί Od. 24.535; οὐδέ οἱ ὕπνος πῖπτεν ἐπὶ βλεφάροις Hes. Fr. 188.4; ἐπὶ γᾷ S. Ant. 134 (lyr.); πρὸς πέδῳ E. Ba. 605; πρὸς ἀγκάλαις Id. Ion 962; ἀμφὶ σώμασίν τινων A. Ag. 326: with a Prep. of motion first in Hes., Πληϊάδες π. ἐς πόντον Op. 620; [ ποταμὸς] εἰς ἅλα Th. 791; εἰς ἄντλον E. Hec. 1025 (lyr.); ἐπὶ γᾶν π. αἷμα A. Ag. 1019 (lyr.); ἐπὶ στόμα X. Cyn. 10.13; πρὸς οὖδας E. Hec. 405.

data.quote: οὐδέ οἱ ὕπνος πῖπτεν ἐπὶ βλεφάροις

children.definition: Hom. with Advs. of motion as well as of rest, χαμάδις π. Il. 7.16, 15.714, etc.; χαμαὶ π. 4.482, cf. 14.418, etc.; π. ἔραζε 12.156, cf. Od. 22.280.
ἀπʼ ὤμων χαμαὶ πέσε Il. 16.803; ἀπʼ οὐρανοῦ A. Fr. 44.3; ἀπό τινος ὄνου Pl. Lg. 701d; ἐκ χειρῶν π. ἡνία Il. 5.583; π. ἐκ νηός Od. 12.417; πεσὼν ἐκ νηὸς ἀποφθίμην ἐνὶ πόντῳ 10.51.

data.quote: πεσὼν ἐκ νηὸς ἀποφθίμην ἐνὶ πόντῳ

children.definition: π. ἐπί τι fall upon, Euc. 3.11, Archim. Fluit. 2.8, al., Apollon.Perg. Con. 1.2; but π. ἐπί τι, ποτί τι, intersect, meet, Archim. Con.Sph. 16, Spir. 15; π. διά τινος pass through, Id. Con.Sph. 17; π. κατά τινος Id. Sph.Cyl. 1 Def. 2; ἐπί τι κατά τινα Apollon.Perg. Con. 1.2.

children.label: I
children.definition: πίπτειν ἔν τισι fall violently upon, attack, ἐνὶ νήεσσι πέσωμεν Il. 13.742 (but ἐν νήεσσι πεσόντες tumbling into the ships, 2.175); ἐν βουσὶ π. S. Aj. 375 (lyr.); Ἔρως, ὃς ἐν κτήμασι π. Id. Ant. 782 (lyr.); ἐπʼ ἀλλήλοισι, of combatants, Hes. Sc. 379, cf. 375; πρὸς μῆλα καὶ ποίμνας S. Aj. 1061 ; πρὸς πύλαις A. Th. 462.
throw oneself down, fall down, πρὸς βρέτη θεῶν ib. 185 ; ἀμφὶ σὸν γόνυ E. Hec. 787; ἐς γόνατα on oneʼs knees, of a wrestler, Simon. 156 ; ἐς τὸν ὦμον Ar. Eq. 571.

children.label: II
children.definition: fall in battle, πῖπτε δὲ λαός Il. 8.67, etc.; οἱ πεπτωκότες the fallen, X. Cyr. 1.4.24 ; νέκυες πίπτοντες Il. 10.200; νεκροὶ περὶ νεκροῖς πεπτωκότες E. Ph. 881 ; πεσήματα . . πέπτωκε δοριπετῆ νεκρῶν Id. Andr. 653 ; π. ὑπὸ Ἀθηναίων Hdt. 9.67 ; ὡς . . θάμνοι πρόρριζοι πίπτουσι . . , ὣς ἄρʼ ὑπʼ Ἀτρεΐδῃ πῖπτε κάρηνα Τρώων Il. 11.157, cf. 500, etc. ; τὸ Περσῶν ἄνθος οἴχεται πεσόν A. Pers. 252.

data.quote: ὡς . . θάμνοι πρόρριζοι πίπτουσι . . , ὣς ἄρʼ ὑπʼ Ἀτρεΐδῃ πῖπτε κάρηνα Τρώων

children.definition: fall, be ruined, δόμον δοκοῦντα κάρτα νῦν πεπτωκέναι Id. Ch. 263, cf. Pl. Phlb. 22e; πεσεῖν . . πτώματʼ οὐκ ἀνασχετά A. Pr. 919, cf. Pl. La. 181b ; στάντες τʼ ἐς ὀρθὸν καὶ πεσόντες ὕστερον S. OT 50 ; ἀβουλίᾳ, ἐξ ἀβουλίας π., Id. El. 429, 398 ; ἀπὸ σμικροῦ κακοῦ Id. Aj. 1078 ; of an army, μεγάλα πεσόντα πρήγματα ὑπὸ ἡσσόνων Hdt. 7.18, cf. Th. 2.89 ; ὁ Ξέρξεω στρατὸς αὐτὸς ὑπʼ ἑωυτοῦ ἔπιπτε Hdt. 8.16 ; of a city, π. δορί E. Hec. 5.

data.quote: στάντες τʼ ἐς ὀρθὸν καὶ πεσόντες ὕστερον
ὁ Ξέρξεω στρατὸς αὐτὸς ὑπʼ ἑωυτοῦ ἔπιπτε

children.definition: fall, sink, ἄνεμος πέσε the wind fell, Od. 19.202 (but in Hes. Op. 547, Βορέαο πεσόντος is used for ἐμπεσόντος, falling on, blowing on one): metaph, πέπτωκεν κομπάσματα A. Th. 794, cf. S. Ant. 474 : c. dat., ταῖς ἐλπίσι πεσεῖν fail in oneʼs hopes, Plb. 1.87.1.
fall short, fail, Pl. Phd. 100e ; of a playwright, fail, Ar. Eq. 540.

children.label: III
children.definition: πίπτειν ἔκ τινος fall out of, lose a thing, unintentionally, σοι ἐκ θυμοῦ πεσέειν fall out of, lose thy favour, Il. 23.595 ; ἐξ ἐλπίδων π. E. Fr. 420.5 ; τοὔμπαλιν π. φρενῶν Id. Hipp. 390 ; also of set purpose, ἐξ ἀρκύων π. escape from . . , A. Eu. 147 ; ἔξω τῶν κακῶν Ar. Ra. 970.

πολλὴν ἐς κακότητα π. Thgn. 42 ; εἰς ἄτην Sol. 13.68 ; εἰς δουλοσύνην Id. 9.4 ; ἐς δάκρυα Hdt. 6.21 ; ἐς νόσον A. Pr. 478 ; εἰς ἔρον, ἔριν, ὀργήν, φόβον, ἀνάγκας, E. IT 1172, Fr. 578.8, Or. 696, Ph. 69, Th. 3.82 ; also ἐν γυιοπέδαις π. Pi. P. 2.41 ; ἐν μέσοις ἀρκυστάτοις S. El. 1476 ; ἐν φόβῳ E. Or. 1418 (lyr.) ; ἐν σολοικισμῷ Luc. Sol. 3; πρὸς τόλμαν S. Ichn. 11 : c. dat. only, π. δυσπραξίαις Id. Aj. 759 ; αἰσχύνῃ Id. Tr. 597, etc.; οὐκ ἔχω ποῖ γνώμης πέσω I know not which way to turn, ib. 705.
